Previous thread: >>6331844

What is /ALT/?
If you're looking for a place to post your cartooning then you've found the right general. This is /ic/s 1st and only merged hub where both Eastern and Western stylization can coexist peacefully, hence the double title.
>Rules & Guidelines
(1) Any form of cartooning is welcome; so submit and receive feedback from others. (2) Please resize your images before posting. (3) Share your knowledge and (4) Remember to not be afraid of asking for critique. Most importantly, keep discussion at a civil level
>I came for anime. Why does the image OP say cartoons general?
To distinguish from the anime study thread (janitor supported). Please post your studies there and personal work goes here.
------
>Community Resources
>Tag the OP if you want a resource included here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6465082
>What kind of benefits are you looking for?
>In this case, what do You want out of art?
I honestly don't know. I just get ideas that I think are worth realizing (but require very different skill sets to execute). I get super hyped for the final product, I finish it, and then reality sets in.
I'm asking /fag/ for advice because /fag/ at least seems to enjoy what they do.

I don't know if I do what I do out of boredom, delusions of grandeur or what. When I finish something, I get thoughts like "oh, well that was a waste of time and nobody cares about it, I should have spent this time doing something else". But then I get the next idea, and the cycle starts again.

I feel like I'm stuck in a catch-22 where I'll be disappointed in myself if I do nothing, but I'll always be disappointed by what I make.

It could be general negative thoughts from not having close friends or social status, but that's not easily fixed. It's difficult for me to build a circle around my hobbies because I jump ship too often to really "get good" at things (and being a /pol/cel doesn't help).

If I was smart, I would channel this energy into making some kind of soulless moneymaking machine, but alas. I can't learn to be content with vidya, weed and anime porn like normal people.

I think the TL;DR is that I keep chasing the dragon trying to make the next big thing, but I get easily discouraged and don't stick with things or chase trends.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6465582
It sounds like you're surrounding yourself with negative situations that'll never happen. Instead, why even worry about what ifs and just concern yourself about those issues Once you get to them (if they even ever come up). Overall, you're just over thinking and allowing your mind to wonder about possible negative outcomes that'll just never happen.
>I feel like I'm stuck in a catch-22 where I'll be disappointed in myself if I do nothing, but I'll always be disappointed by what I make.
I used to have this type of emotion. But in my case, I'd complete a drawing, be happy with it, and convince myself that I can never make anything as good ever again, and take me hours (sometimes days) to get the courage to draw up something again. I repeat this cycle upon each drawing, but now when I hear that voice I let it hang out with me. Instead of feeling doom, I'm just like "lmao you might be right" and just start on the next drawing soon after.
Overall, these emotions are gonna be hard to defeat. But instead of removing them, try to be friends with them. And you'll see why said emotions are making you think the way you are. Otherwise, you really have nothing to lose.

drawing furry stuff has leveled up my ability to draw figures so much because I want them to be in particular poses and have interesting designs. I'm >>6464532
and I've had some thoughts on the subject since I posted.

If one's parents are furries and this information is concealed from children, it would probably stem from concern regarding an audience.

>Child viewing parents
The earliest role models of competence in a child's life is the parents (and most impactful in most cases) and the goal of the parents (presuming care and responsability) is to guide the child's growth to become something functional to society, and also the audience/environment of schools.

Furry parents probably would withhold this because there's a lot of different places/people one may end up hanging out with within the fandom given that there's a huge output of porn and some very vocal weirdos that drown out the more normal ones.

Word getting out to a kid's friends might also make the "Anon's parents are weirdos" and lead to potential embarrassment from peers.

The parents also do not yet know what their child's likes/dislikes are and given that they will be housing the child for 18 or more years, everyone being cohesive is important, both nuclear family and external.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6474152
hopefully someone will give you better pointers but from my limited understanding:
1. line width counts, use width to accent different areas, currently your whole drawing uses a total of 2 different thicknesses for outline + detail lines
2. you need to use more lines to define shapes, normally you'd do this with shading which you have done and is nice but that should be a *secondary* component, every region that has any roundness whatsoever and pops out from the perspective of the "camera" could have a line to accent it, like on the butts, on the face around the cheeks etc.
check a *lot* of cel-shaded art and do studies on simple objects to get a feel for it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6474152
>>6474199
Cel-shading is just consolidating a range of values into a few shades. So studying values in general will give you the skills you need to reduce them down.
As with any skill, it's better to cultivate the proper foundation before you start trying to simplify things.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6413837
So Copic itself is a brand. I'm not sure if it's the OG alcohol based brush marker, but it's basically the standard. I would have recommended Prismacolor last year if you didn't want to splurge on Copics, but I think they're discontinuing the line since I've been seeing them on major clearance at every art store. With that being said, you could easily get a good deal. I personally prefer Copics over all of the alternate brands (Ohuhu is my least favorite and I think they give Instagram/YouTube artists free sets for the good reviews because they kinda suck in person). If you want new, you can buy them for cheapest on Blick. After Christmas, you'll see a lot of sets for sale on sites like Mercari and that's where I got mine for a really good deal. I like that Copics are refillable, and they get a lot cheaper to use when you're refilling them. Other good Copic alternate brands I like are Kuretake and Tombow (make sure not to accidentally get their water markers). Hope this helps.

posts.com:
>>6423644
read 'drawing lessons from the great masters' by robert beverly hale.
practice drawing cylinders and spheres until you can draw them in such a way that they're so good they look like an optical illusion. drawing cubes is to condition your mind for perspective so you should do that as well. by practicing these shapes, your paintings will take on their nature. as an example; if you drill proficiency of spheres into your artistic ability, you will be automatically better at drawing breasts.
the book i mentioned will teach you the fundamentals so that you are well-quipped to navigate the various aspects of art. it moreso teaches you how to think like an artist, rather than simply telling you what to think.
you can already do hands better than ai so at least you've got that going for you.

That's really great. How do you get the features so accurate to the ref? What kind of sketch do you do first?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6460515
It's good that you took the time to finish it. Think of the first parts of the drawing step as being more important to the final work than anything else. Check all of your proportions to your reference, and when you aren't sure about something then you'll know what gaps in your knowledge you have to fill in. Be very careful not to simply copy what you see without thinking about it, as you'll grow very fast by being mindful of what you're doing. Keep finishing your painting like you've done here, and enjoy it. Keep sharing it with us.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6460526
With the grid. I just draw the important outlines. the pencil lines would be as detailed as this pic from google. Important contours such as the clavicle would also be marked with a line.
I take advantage of the very fast drying time of acrylic paint, I can just slather on colours without regard if it actually matches the reference image and I'll fix it on subsequent layers. This is why I prefer it to oil.

The only advantage Wacom still has in the screenless tablet market is build quality, and even then that's the least of your concerns outside of XP-PEN loose nib, which Huion and even fucking Ugee have fixed.

>>6471222
>Are they worth the exorbitant price tag?
Depends on what you're looking for. The Cintiq Pro 27 is the most natural feeling tablet I have ever used in some 20+ years, where working on it really removes that nagging feeling of having to double check your strokes before you make them thanks to how accurate marks are to your intent.
For the average person that can barely hold a pen to begin with and thinks that making 1248 wrong strokes but ctrl+z'ing after every one of them until they get the "right" stroke, no you probably won't be able to appreciate the difference.
But if you work with analogue mediums regularly because of how responsive they are and miss that when moving to digital systems, yes you very well might find the latest Wacom gear worth the price.

... i am sorry for your loss.

you should have been less ambitious with those pose and instead stick to what you know. no-ref means you can't go crazy unless you've learned it before, you actually are supposed to stay in your comfort zone a bit more. eventually you can do even unpracticed stuff without ref if you do it often enough. However 90% the reason why good artists can do things is because they've done it before and are used to it. so you can't act like you ought to magically know how to do something you never actually learned.

the only other thing i can think of for advice is 2 things.
1: Go radically in the opposite direction. Avoid all meme advice completely, only do something if you yourself see that it works. repeat what usually works for you. None of the memes work right? You should know that better than anyone now. By not following memes, you are simply avoiding what usually doesn't work.

2: pay very close attention to if you're about to do something that usually doesn't work. If you catch yourself doing it, STOP, reorient, do anything else.
next, If you notice whenever you do x, it usually does come out nice, try doing it more. The real trick here is in developing your awareness, that you are constantly checking to see if you are doing something that leads you on a path that leads to a bad drawing, frustration, and whatever. Actually apply this, it is great for helping with stagnation, it's a bit of a natural corrector

>>6477558
>light and shadow
light being emitted from a light source tend to reflect and spread in bouncing rays, until they reach your eyes sensors.

Your eye genetics determine what colors and what intensity of values they can detect.
In practical terms light simply follows another vanishing point towards a light source, and you use perpective techniques to draw it properly.

>color harmonies
arragement of colors that has specific effects or uses.
By example, monochrome pallethes tend to have an unique mood compared to oposite or dual oposite color pallethes.

Such effect is related to the psychological effect each color has.
By example, a monochrome blue pallethe will have a melancholical effect, while one with yellow black and red will have an evil and dark effect.

Generally it follows a 60/30/10 proportion usually in most character designs.

>Shape design
Shape psychology relates to 3 basic shapes.
Cube = Reliable and hardworking.
Spiky = Dangerous and agressive.
Circle = Feminine and weak, cute also.

Shape design is basically designing your character to be a certain % of one of the 3 shapes, in most of it's shapes.

Study from realism books, learn proper gesture/figure drawing, go through your Vilppu's and Bridgmans, only once you get good at realistic figure drawing should you pursue stylization like anime, otherwise it just weights you down. You have good lines and a decent grasp of perspective, and your hands look good, but yeah, take the begpill, humble yourself, and go through the right steps in order.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6477362
I feel like people like OP is a lot more common than one might think. Somewhat technically competent but due to lacking a clear vision of WHAT exactly they want to do with said skills, they end up plateauing alongside their skills because I highly doubt you ACTUALLY "studied and grinded" that long and not achieve anything. If your goal was to simply draw good, then you'd have become someone like Kim Jung Gi that can draw entire pages with one stroke. Since that doesn't seem to be the case, you were absolutely not studying unless you thought of it as some sort of RPG where you slowly gained experience points then level up which is retarded. You need to be as specific as you can with what exactly you want.

In my friend's case, he wants to draw a manga/story and here's an example of one of his drawings. He has much, much more detailed ones and a million times better than me despite the fact that he claims that he wasn't doing too much of the raw grinding a lot of beginners do like making a million boxes. Easily high int. And in my case, I want to be competent enough to be able to make soulful art for a video game I want to make. Was symbol drawing just a few months ago and I barely even drew. Now I'm much more efficient because I can specifically say what exactly I need to be able to do to make said "game" because that in on itself is too vague. Backgrounds, main characters, interactable NPC, uninteractable NPCs... etc. All of those can be broken even further down like with character's clothes, what food they eat, how they talk, how their body looks relative to everyone, how they pee, how do they fuck and react to certain things? Stuff like that. Once I did that, not only was I able to discipline myself better to keep drawing, I'm able to bring more better results compared to when everything was just vague. I hope I'm making sense.

just draw™ edition

If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.
Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:
1. screenshot the image and post that instead
2. change camera capture settings to something smaller
3. send to computer and resize in MSPaint

READ THE STICKY:
Completed: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uwaXKU7ev6Tw_or__o8ARpUb6r2rCZYJGqwSFV9AD98/edit
New collaborative sticky (anyone can edit): https://hackmd.io/UMnZVhNITW-T2wZpHw6d0Q
Old: http://www.squidoo.com/how-to-draw-learn

RECOMMENDED BOOKS FOR BEGINNERS:
Read the sticky

TRY TO BE ACTIVE AND GIVE PEOPLE SOME FEEDBACK.
When giving feedback, avoid vague "advice" - point what's wrong and try to give the anon you're quoting a clear direction to improve their art (study heads < watch THIS VIDEO about head structure, read THIS SECTION of THIS ARTIST'S BOOK, etc).
You, feedback seeking anon, should also try to be clear and concise when asking for critique/help. When posting your artwork, say what you want help with, and what's your goal with the study/artwork.

One can have talent in anything, as in the ability to quickly understand and process information, but even the most talented individual will never get good at a thing if he doesn't actively train himself.

What you want is struggle, the more you struggle the more you learn, unless you're low iq then no amount of struggle will ever teach you anything.
Talented people may have an easier time getting their foot into anything, but at the first sign of struggle, their talent in whichever thing they chose to purse, doesn't help them anymore.
>How much of drawing is talent?
20% is talent.
35% is intelligence and learning from your failures.
30% is actual practice and failing even more.
15% is stop giving a shit what other cunts think of your work

"Talent" is a shitty concept and cope that completely devalues the hard work artists put into improving their craft. To summarize I think you're working with a poor reference of a woman who's had a lot of plastic surgery.
You won't get a drawing that looks right using her as reference.
The pose is also a little too symmetrical to translate into a good drawing.
You should also avoid those unconfident lines when doing lineart. Practice drawing clean lines in a single stroke.
Hope this helps.

Forgot to mention you should also study line weight.
Lines closer to the light source or further from the viewer should be thinner and vice versa.

yeah this is what I meant ( or at least tried to). where I see many people failing animating by mesh is:
1. only using linear interpolation, so lack of weight
2. using the same images/parts in for the whole
cycle, this limit the expressiveness and force of action.

If you are interested try doing this for the tits and pussy lips have 3 distinct images (idle, pushing max position and pulling min position) use the idle for the most part of the animation and in the finishing the movement of pull/push change the image (and possibly also the mesh and vertexes)

t. old opentoonz dev and helped a few people with this kind of animation

>>6476796
>Can you even spot the difference
Yes, but to fully appreciate traditional it helps to look at the original, or as close as possible (really good print quality). I have some art editions of my favorite artists (like Wallace Wood) and the amount of subtlety and detail is incredible, I've never seen digital art that compares.
There's a reason people pay top dollar for fine art, original comic art, etc., and even pay hundreds for artist's editions and high quality art books. For the connoisseur nothing else compares.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6476796
>>6477052
Also, it depends on the artist. A lot of comic artists, like the OP pic, just do basic linework and fill in areas of black. Nothing wrong with this method, many great artists (like Mike Mignola) work this way. But it is a method that is easy to replicate in digital.
To get a full appreciation of traditional, it helps to look at an artist who does something particular in the medium, like Robert Crumb. His subtle crosshatching and even some of the imperfections unique to his work would undoubtedly be lost in digital.

This explains it well. There is that tactile quality to traditional. The "too clean" thing resonates, which is why I enjoy artists like Crumb, there's a grittiness to the work that is not just a byproduct of style but also medium.
Also in painting, there's a warmth to say, a Frazetta, that digital painting doesn't come close to. But that's for those better educated in painting to dissect.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The right is vastly superior to the left, all you have to do is look at the details, the linework has more more variety and shape difference, less straight lines do to digital smoothing, etc.
Just look at the hands and claws to compare how they differ or the inside thigh detail, particularly on the left one the thigh muscles came out sharp and angular and it doesn't really work well for organics.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6477823
Yes, the shapes are worse in the digital version, but that has nothing to do with it being digital. You can make the exact same shapes, use the exact same line weight in digital and all you'd be missing is the subtle, variations in value when the ink is slightly thinner or reflecting the light from the scanner or whatever. However, these variations in tone are unintentional and typically leveled out for print/the next step in the production process. What's left is totally reproducible in digital, at which point it's just a matter of whichever medium the inker prefers. A good analog original does look very nice though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6477844
Do the exact same stroke on digital and physical and digital will never be able to catch all the exactitude and subtleties of physical.
You'll have to find ways to compensate for it on digital, by redoing it over and over again, by going slower, by constantly adjusting the settings, etc. But it'll still never be the same and are still shortcomings none the less.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6477873
>Do the exact same stroke on digital and physical and digital will never be able to catch all the exactitude and subtleties of physical.
Okay, but you shouldn't do the exact same stroke. They're different tools. You could say the exact same thing about a brush and a chopstick.
Besides, anything that's displayed on your monitor can be reproduced on that same monitor. The only thing that can't be reproduced is the original itself. Not photophraphy of the original, but the actual piece of paper that is inked, and as such the differences can only be perceived when looking at the actual original in the flesh.
In OP's example the analog drawing is just a better drawing. It doesn't prove that digital is worse or anything, just that in this circumstance the digital drawing came out worse for whatever reason.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6474281
>Do you often have vivid dreams?
Sometimes, but they tend to be incredibly disjointed and nonsensical (I'm in the car with my father, pulling into an underground parking garage, and the down ram morphs into a hallway of a school I've never attended but somehow I'm in middle school there and am now walking down the hall, but still aware of the parking garage connection)
>Do you remember most of your dreams right after waking up?

>Do you have strong memory?
It's spotty. I remember structural layouts of placed I havent been to in over a decade and random things from preschool, but at the same time forget people I've met in the past year and barely remember anything about grad school. Sometimes I struggle to remember what I was talking about if interrupted during conversation.
>How far back can you remember your first memory?
I remember sticking a popcorn kernel up my nose. This was sometime before preschool, I think. So maybe age 3? 4?
>Are your linguistic skills stronger than mathematical skills?

>How many languages do you speak?
One. I used to be fairly proficient in Spanish and knew some Japanese, but I haven't used them in years.
>Do you have vivid imagination?
I can see things pretty clearly in my mind's eye, but mostly just things I've seen before. I can create new images and see them in my mind, but I wouldn't say they're particularly vivid. I can come up with interesting stories and scenarios.
>Are you often daydreaming?
Yes. If I'm not having pathetic waifu fantasies, I'm thinking about what to draw or what would be a good way to commit suicide.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6472850
Da Vinci's treatise on painting?
https://www.gutenberg.org/files/46915/46915-h/46915-h.htm

Painting back then was in its infancy; its teaching is much more "recipe-based" and less systematic than it is today ("if you want to paint that kind of stuff, then do this and that"; Cennini is a great example of it).

For instance, back then, color wasn't understood as hue/value/saturation. Such systems aren't perfect, but they are incredibly useful to handle colors. My point is, even if you aim at studying ancient techniques, don't neglect modern refinements.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6460785
I think that the process of painting/drawing a pictore is so different from prompting that you have to doubt if the people labelling themselves as "ai artists" right now would ever have gone through the trouble of learning how to draw properly without ai. Sure, some of them were trying to learn it at some point but so were a lot of other people who never had the patience to actually become good at it and eventually ended up moving on to other things. Promting just happened to what this partucular group moved on to but I seriously doubt many of them would have become "proper" artists if not for ai. They'd more likely just be playing video games or shitposting on reddit instead.

In the end, comparing drawing to prompting is like comparing someone taking a photo of a landscape to someone making a painting of that same landscape. Sure, they might come up with results that look similar but the process in itself is so different that one person would most likely not enjoy what the other is doing and vice versa. Are there some people who like both painting and photography? Sure, just like some will combine the two into a single artwork but there are also plenty of people who only enjoy one of the two and there's nothing wrong with that. It's simply two different ways to produce an image.

Not saying this to defend ai by the way, I still think the way it was produced and marketed is shady as fuck and I'm all for regulations to stop these schizos from creating their AGI dystopia. But I also think saying "why would you prompt if you can just learn how to draw" is disingenuous in a way, since most of the current prompters likely would never have learned how to draw anyway, with or without the existence of ai

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6459289
It's actually doing the opposite. Most AI artists are just shit at using the AI, but it's genuinely leading us to more variation.
That's part of why the hysteria around all this started with Artstation-type "industry" artists. They spent their careers cultivating their styles to be corporate-friendly so they can hop from temporary job to temporary job brownnosing and trying to win based on groveling to art directors for a perma spot. They're literally all almost interchangeable though, by design. Companies want to be able to let people go and hire new ones without the brand image changing much. Think of how Wizards of the Coast's Magic The Gathering changed around when they started letting go all the trad painters in the mid 2000s, vs how little their "look" has really changed since around 2010.

I have seen people use AI to mishmash all kinds of crazy things and it really speaks volumes to how many niches are out there for artists to jump on. You want to draw coomer art in the old SNK style from the 90s? There's people who would LOVE that. You want to draw something like a combo of Saint Seiya and the chunkiness Jack Kirby? Someone out there is going to want you to draw their OC like that.

Most of the AI shit is generic but most peoples' tastes are generic because most people don't actually give a shit about art or interact with it outside of TV/Movies and SOMETIMES AAA games. More art exposure = more taste developed = more people wanting their specific custom ideas made by non-ai artists (and/or becoming artists themselves).

Yea I constantly see shit nobody was making before.
You show me people who were painting a combo of 1800s garden scenes with anime women.
You show me the artist who was making "[Thing] as an 80s [genre] movie" before.

The fact is nobody was doing this shit before and now the people with fucked up ideas can struggle with trying to describe it to a dumb text interpreter to get some semblence of a visual output, making something close enough to communicate "the idea of it" with even modest skill. And then maybe they'll take that to a non-AI artist as a reference!

Doing that process with a non-AI artist is immensely risky on both a cost and time level, for BOTH the artist and the other person. The artist may have to deal with numerous corrections, and the commissioner would have to first scour the internet for someone who CAN do such a thing and gather reference material that fits it, before having the interaction difficulty with an artist, the monetary cost, and having to pay for more corrections or going to another artist after for "this but better" if the experience and result was lackluster. Skipping that whole first step to the "this but better" part is huge for productivity for both commissioners AND artists.

>>6460328
To understand the meaning of "Just Draw" one must first understand that the true definition of talent is the ability to learn how to do something well with little to no instruction.

Now that we have that definition out of the way, we can begin with why the "just draw" phenomenon exists and why some people are able to actually benefit from the "just draw" when others seem to find it to be a trap.

Once we understand the definition of talent, we can now see why the "just draw" phrase is thrown around as if it was the most enlightened advice ever given. It is not because it actually works for everyone but rather that it works for anyone who has an innate ability to draw--innate not meaning "born with" but rather a proclivity towards drawing that creates a natural ability to learn things.

In order for "just draw" to actually work, one must have talent in drawing. This talent will allow you to be able to draw for hours and learn from your work and mistakes without any instruction whatsoever--though instruction could never hurt. If one does not have talent in drawing, they must seek out help in order to improve or else they will stagnate as pointed out by this anon: >>6463757

Basically, if you don't have talent, learning to draw will much harder and even if you do end up attaining a certain level of skill, your art will never be as good as most of the worst works from artists that do have talent which is why you have to find a reason to actually pursue art. You have to have a purpose as to why you are pursuing it rather than just the blind ambition of being able to draw le cute animu grill.

The real question we need to ask here is that if you do not possess such talent, would you still continue to draw? That is the real question you need to ask yourself here. That will allow you to determine whether or not to continue or if you should just quit.

>>6471926
>The Process of Drawing
Here we go, I'll try to explain as best as I could.

The difference between being able to perform and being able to teach is based on the understanding on the process of that specific skill. Performers tend to not understand the process of being able to learn something and therefore are the worst teachers in that field. They tended to have received their skill by sheer mileage and have often taken decades to get to where they currently are. As they have not properly analyzed their approach and why they do certain things, they have an intuitive understanding of drawing which only helps them. Basically, performers cannot teach and can only perform. This is where you get the advice to "just draw" because performers tend to be the ones that actually take this advice seriously and tend to get good by sheer mileage rather than anything concrete that you can teach to anyone.

Teachers understand a skill at a much higher level than performers and while they may not be as good as the performers, they will often coach the performers regardless. Note how coaches in sports aren't usually better than the players on the team. (If they were, they'd be mentors not teachers or coaches.) A teacher must have a very high level of understanding of whatever skill they are pursuing as they have to properly explain each and every step--otherwise, they're wasting everyone's time.

For instance, if we were to bring this back to drawing, lets say a beginner creates a drawing. You notice that the drawing is shit but because you are a performer, you can't exactly explain why it is shit. You can say something like, "the forms are off" or the "perspective is off" but you can't really delve exactly as to why the drawing is really bad, much less provide useful resources to practice from.

The teacher will be able to hyper-analyze a drawing and know exactly what the issues are what that beginner to study.

Most people on here are performers, NOT teachers.

Just Draw, to a beginner, implies that they just continue to draw their bad symbols over and over again until they eventually improve. It DOES NOT imply--as others have erroneously said--you objectively look at your drawings and analyze why they are bad. This is not something a beginner--especially those who started drawing late--will be able to do as they do not understand the process of drawing.

Because this is a board dedicated towards the critiquing of discussing of artwork, it was quite strange for me to discover that the only piece of advice that was thrown around was "just draw." When you pursue any other skill, you never hear anyone just say, "just play the piano" or "just sing" or "just code" etc. There are typically well defined fundamentals that even those who literally just started are going to be aware of such as playing the scales as a pianist or learning the absolute basics of coding--though coding is a bit arbitrary to be honest.

It wasn't until I started to draw a lot more that I realized that most people on here don't actually analyze what they are doing. They kind of treat it like a video game where they simply play and play and play the game until they maybe get good rather than sitting back and analyzing what strategies are the best, what their weak-spots are, and what is worth practicing. This isn't to say you focus too much on strategies, obviously there is a level of performance that must take place, but completely neglecting it for "just playing" or "just drawing" is quite ridiculous.

>>6460328
since learning takes a bunch of time, the best advice they could give you is trust the years of hard work and eventually you'll see the results.

to get good results, it would make sense to analyze your piece after you've gained enough symbol making abilities and think (not emotionally, constructively)

> "OK, this I lack perspective skills"

this is quite simple to fix, perspective is very tactical, with enough grids you will see where you made a mistake, fix it, remember, draw enough to train your muscle memory and you'll draw buildings in perspective in no time,
if your hand is witty enough you can doodle something abstract in perspective. But to that you need to think with more IQ points,
there are some people breaking down every type of perspective while giving basic overalls on it, then apply into your art

>I don't know how to draw circular, soft shapes

from drawing a lot your hand should get smooth lines quite easily, practice drawing a circle, then lines curving around it, find other shapes from pictures and whatnot, draw a bunch of lines to understand the form, soon instead of blockiness you'll get smoothiness

hate shading? look at how it's done in real life, look at 2 values, thern add a rim light, then maybe really soft shapes with a lighter value, make sure to think how shapes reflect light,
find videos of light traveling across the room, going far and close to the object

you're an artist, and artist observes more than normal people, and if you wanna be a master, you gotta put in some studying into it as well

but never forget this, if you love drawing, you better draw your hands off and "just draw", and we promise you'll get gut

or take things slow, just remember to have fun in it too

Stop being Afraid.

In my own case,what I present to the public is usually very different from the source material that I physically draw with ballpoint pens,and pencil for intentionally moulding into two dimensional sculpture that are my finished panels. But what I have "most" of are over 180 pages of a sprawling tale of Jeremey Prickles and a good 70 pages were literally storyboards of when I was able to Do It Properly, which means everything is made of separately drawn chunks pounded by Photoshop into story, So I drew it using the sketchbooks I was dragging into waiting rooms,and an epic story sprung from a random sketch of a demon head. It has both moments of revelation and whiplash pangs at your heart strings. I ordered a flatbed scanner so I can properly showcase my recent art,and the tale I am now telling,and the decision I have made. I am going to be 58 soon,and I am pondering how to proceed. >>6472842
>>6471842
A lot of people don't have concrete ideas of what they want to draw, or even what they like a lot of the time. Sometimes this is due to a "copying is bad" mind poison, sometimes it's due to a false idea that to "be a master" means that drawing entirely from imagination is the skill to practice.

In general, though, it's that they haven't made a conscious effort to examine their own tastes to where they have anything to say. It can be a compartmentalization issue - happens with coomer artists a lot, where they filter everything "not sexy" into a different mental box and so put almost no new inspiration into their "sexy art box" on the daily.

It could also be a complete disconnect between what they like to consume and what they like to produce - for some, a motivation to create is because of a lack of met desires with what currently exists. In this case they need to examine LOTS of things to know what to "not" make, which by extension gives them the mental negative-space shape of what fits the criteria of what they DO want to make.

Finally, unrelated to the other two, some people really need ultra basic help. Proper posture/desk setup for maximum arm movement is what is missing when a lot of people don't get how to draw from your shoulder, for example. And "How to use a ruler to measure things while drawing" is another, since some people, again, fuck up their mental compartments and remove all other skills from the "drawing" box. The aforementioned inability to compare to reference accurately (along without understanding that tracing can be a tool to help) is another. These are all things that are even more basic than what people call "Fundamentals," they're the kind of shit that almost nobody teaches or talks about outside of an atelier or private instruction.

Most people outside of this hellhole that are parroting "just draw" are assuming that those they speak with are just suffering from a confidence issue like performance anxiety.

Pic rel

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6477369
To expand on point 2 and 3:
Just because someone likes horror doesn't mean they want to draw horror. They may be consumed by loving horror, but want to draw say - something more like Hamtaro or Sanrio.

But if they absolutely can't bear interacting with those media, then they're in a tough spot. They need to really examine what they like in great detail. A structure that works is a venn diagram:

>What I can do as good as them (for beginners this will be mostly empty, this exercise is repeated yearly or every six months or so)
>What elements I want to copy from them
>What elements of theirs I don't want to incorporate into my work

So to continue the example, they may want to draw cute shit and use bold lines and huge eyes, but with some kind of "implied story threads" that are more like the cute, cozy energy found in drawings people do of POKEMON, not hamtaro or sanrio.

If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.
Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:
1. screenshot the image and post that instead
2. change camera capture settings to something smaller
3. send to computer and resize in MSPaint

READ THE STICKY:
Completed: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uwaXKU7ev6Tw_or__o8ARpUb6r2rCZYJGqwSFV9AD98/edit
New collaborative sticky (anyone can edit): https://hackmd.io/UMnZVhNITW-T2wZpHw6d0Q
Old: http://www.squidoo.com/how-to-draw-learn

RECOMMENDED BOOKS FOR BEGINNERS:
Read the sticky

TRY TO BE ACTIVE AND GIVE PEOPLE SOME FEEDBACK.
When giving feedback, avoid vague "advice" - point what's wrong and try to give the anon you're quoting a clear direction to improve their art (study heads < watch THIS VIDEO about head structure, read THIS SECTION of THIS ARTIST'S BOOK, etc).
You, feedback seeking anon, should also try to be clear and concise when asking for critique/help. When posting your artwork, say what you want help with, and what's your goal with the study/artwork.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6474733
Sketches look better because:
1) you chicken scratch/draw multiple lines and your brain imagines a better drawing than what you've actually drawn
2) you draw big confident strokes when you sketch but small slow-moving cautious strokes when you ink
With digital ink lines I try to adjust the stabiliser.
When it comes to painting keep in mind you're not just working with line anymore, you can't just suggest the form and shape, you have to be more specific, so if the form and shape and lighting isn't exciting colour can kinda ruin the picture.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6475802
if you practice copying references, you get better at copying references
unless your references are simple geometric shapes, you're not going to improve at drawing simple geometric shapes, the word "simple" here is misleading, nothing is simple, you have to learn how to draw a thing before you can turn a different thing into said thing
you know what a cone or prism looks like in the same way you know what a leg or a face looks like, that is to say: you don't really, your brain just tells you that you do and then leaves you on read when you ask for proof
it's why i keep saying that construction is bad for real beginners with the way people here market it as a solution to incompetence rather than a technique like any other

It's just something I've gradually become accustomed to over years of drawing. Started out just drawing things that interested me, and because it looked like crap I looked up any references that could tell me about what I struggled with, and over time just accumulated a feel for it. I'm still a far way away from where I'd like to be, but I've only started drawing daily very recently. Previously it was only a few days a month or so. I'd reccommend something like what you see in the bottom page on my photo where I iterate the same image a few times, focusing in on a certain portion and in an attempt to get it right, then once you've done that you might try to go a step further and draw the same thing from a different angle, but that's pretty advanced.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6474800
Over time I got used to my tablet, and I settled into a sweet spot where I don't adjust as much it anymore. But basically, if you're drawing a big, slow line, turn up stabilisation so that your jittery hands don't affect the smoothness of the line. Turn down stabilisation for light, quick strokes.
It's really a matter of confidence in the end, doing a lot of ink drawings (trad) with no undo can help you get over the "I did it wrong, undo" feeling

>>6476303
ok, go copy some golden era early 2000s CN genndy tartakovsky/craig mccracken characters or anything similiar to that in complexity and do it such that you get them almost perfectly right, good enough to be absolutely, unmistakably on-model proportionally; don't shit it all out on the paper in a matter of seconds and then scribble over it, take the time it needs to be correct, copy the lines, carefully, patiently analyze their sizes, angles and trajectories, no construction; once you get a couple of them right and realize how hard even that is, you'll understand why copying photos of real people at your skill level is a fool's errand
stop doing the loomis method and other techniques that you clearly can't even follow or even draw correctly in and of themselves, you should already be aware of a voice in the back of your head telling you that you can't do it, you can't use it and that it isn't helping you, but i'll go ahead reaffirm that for you: you can't do it, you can't use it, and until you change that, it will only hinder you; it's basically a pre-sketch religious ritual at this point
then go do draw a box to improve your lines and geometry, completely forget all the bullshit about any theory you think you've understood, you haven't understood any of it and that's not entirely your fault, the sticky is full of shit advice that shitters regurgitate in order to fit in

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6474228
I’ve gone through several phases of ‘fun pen’

many years ago I liked the 005 micron because it was so fine, and felt sexy to use. But it is completely impractical to sketch with because the nib wears down so fast.

Then i upgraded my paper from cheap copy paper to heavy smooth card stock. I was super into the 01 micron, until I discovered the plastic nib PN micron. The PN is super robust, and you can get some line weights with it. It draws fast and is my favorite sketching pen.

I used the PN until a buddy got me into using a 2mm lead holder with HB lead. Now for quick sketches I use the lead holder and went back to cheap copy paper. The toothy paper feels really good with the pencil.

Recently, I went back to the 005 on the smooth copy paper for some studies (pic rel). The 005 felt just as good as I had remembered, but you really need to be purposeful and you can’t just dick around and make scribbles or the nib turns to a nub.

Here is the list of pens I thought I would like, but find infuriating
>pocket brush pen
Fuck this thing. It’s too slow, the line weight is nice, but the ink is so thin and weak, I’d rather use a dip pen. I also hate the wavy hand tremors that show up when i draw with it. Definitely not for sketching

>dip pen
The worst pen. The learning curve is just way too high. I spent 2 yrs trying to ink with it. It’s even slower than the brush pen because you have to clean the tip and dip every 2 minutes. Then wait for the ink to dry so you don’t smear it. Probably the most unfun pen I’ve ever used. I never have a good time inking with it. The ink is either too thick or too thin or the nib is worn, the ink splatters, and my desk is covered in soggy ink soaked tissues like I just jerked off a swarm of squid.

posts.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

>>6466732
I don't think you really understand what the term "master study" means judging by the crap you've been spamming anon.

A "master study" implies you're studying from an artist you consider well-rounded and of a higher, established skill level. You do so in order to break down and understand the process behind the picture, akin to reverse-engineering it. It has nothing to do with them being born centuries ago or having their works on a museum's wall. Even studying someone else's study can be considered a master study.
The medium and style said artist is using only matters to you. If you believe Miyazaki's drawings possess something you want to extract and instill into your own art, then he is a master to you and studying his work counts as a master study. Same goes for some famous Twitter artist you look up to.

Forcing an anti-Japanese culture narrative or pretending to objectify what should be valued as masterful or not in the end just tells more about you people's petty complexes more than anything else.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6473037
He's showing the front plane of the pectorals. This plane is bounded laterally by a line from the clavicle (specifically, the point on the front at which the clavicle curves backward) to the bottom outer limit of the pectoral (just a little below/outside the nipple). From that bottom/outer point, an oblique line going toward the point of the shoulder is the base of another triangular plane, which is the side plane of the pectoral.

depends. Some people like oda and kubo could do it in pen. But their work isnt complex and polished. Both Murata and Kishimoto do a pencil draft before inking. So basically anyone who has polished art probably does a draft before inking.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6475504
you can tell if an artist is working off of a sketch or not
if it's very clean, smooth and precise, it's made on top of a sketch, if it's "rough," "expressive" or "loose," it's freehand if the artist is experienced enough, most will do both
your average published, conventionally styled manga(and western comics too, really) is relatively finnicky and laborious to make, full of magic tricks and techniques that have more to do with crafts than arts, to the point where the transition to digital(which is what i'm assuming you're referring to when you say "traditional") adds only a little bit of extra "artificiality" to it, because it always has been, these aren't impressionist ear cutter paintings, they're products made to a standard

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6456218
I had a similar issue and it might sound retarded but try going the exact opposite direction and take some time aside to do whatever you think would be the most miserable, unfun exercise. For me that was copying a Bargue plate. By the end of it you won't have burst into flames and even if it takes way longer than it should've or looks horrible it's not the end of the world and you'll have gotten something out of the experience.
After doing that I became progressively more ok with the idea of doing studies even though I used to be super averse to the very idea of drawing copies since you're going through all that trouble just to reproduce something that's already there. I understood the value theoretically but had no fucking patience to subject myself to it. Sitting down to study and analyze a picture can actually end up being really fun, specially if it's an artist you like. To me this was unthinkable because the only way I had fun before was making shit up and tossing the drawing as soon as I got bored.
Just pick one thing and stick with it, the more you do it the more used you'll get to it. For me, at least, the problem was that I was too used to drawing mindlessly as recreation so studying felt unnatural and scary. It's just a matter of getting used to something unfamiliar.
Again I know it's retardedly simple but I think it's the most reliable solution. Just be consistent with it and eventually the aversion will be gone. You'll always have plenty of time to draw your own stuff for fun, and it'll expand your options.

Either find what you like drawing, get out of a comfort zone, experiment by fucking with different media/styles, or find something else entirely. Art as a profession is something one should take joy in otherwise while the skill may remain, the soul goes away. Art as something for yourself doesn't need to worry about it, and if you don't enjoy it, much as I hate the word, you're just being a poser for likes and (You)s.

Do what you love anon. Draw what you love, draw who you love

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6451437
Practice, simple as.
When I did go to an art school for a bit, I went in expecting to be amongst titans, but I still ended up being a big fish in a small pond, mostly because I've been drawing for longer than most have been alive there.
You just gotta do it over and over again, until eventually you can internalize steps and externally "skip" them, so instead of doing the rough skeleton, your able to go straight to rough details and all of that.
At one point I just went hard mode and exclusively used ball point pen to draw, so no pencil roughs to erase later, just try to make it look good in one go, results turned out to about pic related.
Just practice practice practice

Find the gesture, and exaggerate it. say their torso is bent to the right, and they are in sort of a ( shape, exaggerate that, push their hips more to the left, and the top torso to the right. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6475672
I'm the same.
Just tough it out isn't working if you are like me. I need to feel passionate about something and anxiety blocks me completely.

First you need to get rid of your anxiety. This is hard...but you need to forgive yourself for not meeting your expectation. Work on accepting that you will get better with time but it won't be now. But everytime you draw you will get there eventually. So stop focusing on what you want your picture to be and focus on the small improvements you make on the way. This of course is not simple to do and you have to force yourself to reframe your mindset everytime it reverse into anxiety, self doubt and feeling negative. If you fail to do that..forgive yourself for this to. This is important.

the second thing is to do what I want to do. If i'm motivated everything feels possible. If i'm not...everything seems insurmentable.
But i'm not motivated. Yes...that's why you will need to find a way to make it motivating.
Maybe what would motivate you is to get better at values. So start with values studies...procrastinate...but in the right direction...then try to apply what you learn on what you should do. If it's not good. Redo values studies and try again etc...

Well how to motivate yourself is not easy...but it's possible.

And the last part is. Accept that what you want and what the client needs aren't the same thing. The client is happy with mediocre most of the time and you well get what you want...but not now. But if you trust the process and keep at it eventually you'll get there.
You'll get other clients later. Don't bet everything you have on this one comission...it won't happen anyway.

Be patient. And if you can't get to work because you avoid feeling bad. Then start with forcing yourself to feel bad and sit with the bad feeling for a while...then stop and do something. Then you repeat sitting still and confronting your bad feelings...until you'll get used to confronting those feelings.

Hello, I hope I am not being obnoxious talking about my girlfriend again. But she has true Aphantasia (Cannot see any kind of visual memories in her mind at all).
However, she began drawing around 3 weeks ago and I am training her using a similar path to what Krenz proposes.
So far, I am seeing her progress faster than i did (I stand in stark contrast, as I am I can visualize very well).
Things I've noticed she seems naturally better at.
1.Organizing her process, from the steps on going from sketch to coloring to layer organization
2. She seems to have a better hand to eye coordination, has a lot of patience and works well.
3. Takes a lot more care in detailing, fishing, making something presentable
4. She is able to notice details in things that often go over me, as I am often lost in thought, that comes both for observation and general media consumption

I am curious to see her progress, and I'll likely post more about how effective the training is for anyone else with Aphantasia or who might simply be curious.

Most of us are just executing a procedure here and there trying to bend it toward "what looks good" with trial and error. Sometimes we have a strong idea and try to bend it toward that, but that makes the process harder.

I don't have aphantasia, but I don't have strong visualization abilities, and making visualizations isn't part of my or most other artists process.

I think you have some idealized notion that artists "see something in their mind" and mentally project it onto a page and trace. I'd be surprised if even one human artist on the whole planet does that.

There are artist that *do* have visualization as part of their process, like the late Kim Jung Gi, but another part of the process was building a library of processes by doing drawings from reference of lots of different things.

Draftsman, animators and painters from imagination don't have psychic powers. They just work harder than you and know more than you.

>>6475582
interesting topic. as someone visiting from /x/ I think I have a vague grasp on aphantasia. someone explained it like having a PC running, processing images and all kinds of visuals but then having no monitor connected to that PC. so you know what's going on, you just can't see it on the screen. that fits my situation as well. I do have a memory, I know what I look like or my mother. I just can't project it into my visual field or use my third eye to see it with my mind's eye. I have a friend of mine who can project anything into his sight, we call that hyperphantasia. btw I do have imagination since my "PC is working well". It's different for audio stuff tho. I can hear my thoughts in any voice, imagine music and instruments, sounds and stuff in my head. other senses like smell, touch and taste are less pronounced. I can feel imagined touch to some degree but taste and smell are basically not existent. I do differentiate between the third eye visualization, hypnagogia and dreams. I do dream and I see them just the same as if I'm awake. I do see flashes when tired and shortly before going to sleep. for me that's working alright. but in the waking state I just see black when closing my eyes, I just see black when thinking of a person or an object. I know the underlying concept of it though and memorized the most important details on my mental HDD.

as another anon said here, drawing for me is like starting out on a blank space, knowing what do to in theory, but going in completely blind, building up with each stroke, trial and error, not knowing where the actual drawing goes on paper.

btw some people claim they don't think in words but concepts. also some people can not read a book without moving their mouth to speak the words, because they can't think them in their head. this entire aphantasia thing is to me is so much more than just a lack of visualization. it's the understanding of the workings of our human minds in infinite complexity

they are iron, on both of my designs, the lines are segments, but i can see why one could think they are made out of canvas

because its also works as regular battleship if none of the anti gravitational fuel is available, the flight mode cannot be sustained forever too, because of the liquids properties (has to be kept at a certain temperature and mixture with gases to work/ overheating issues etc.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6473866
Never saw that drawing, but the torso looked blobby to me, and the belly looked rather concave because of the values you used. Also the hips seemed a bit iffy to me. Pic has the value shapes you used in red and blue is the implied form. The belly definition was just my personal preference. You can blur the abs and it wouldn't really matter. About the light, here's a tip, when you compare the rgb sliders of an unlit area and a lit one, and one of the sliders moves in the opposite direction of the rest, there's something strange going on. The exception is when the lit area is the shadow area of another light or when you're straight up changing hues. This is not a hard rule, but something to think about.

>i mean when you couldn't download it and you knew that
I felt stupid after I spent so much time putting together that imagine and re-read your request. You can get a script to do it with Tampermonkey, too; the disadvantage of these methods is that you're still up against a limit of how many pictures you're allowed to access in a given period of time. This limit regenerates pretty quickly, but not *that* fast. Like I said in >>6462087, there are books and collections on there worth many thousands of Gallery Points, and you'd hit your limit pretty quickly downloading those via script - anyone would.

On the plus side, it still doesn't cost any money to use a script ... so there is that.

>>6467345
as somone who just started learning the figure using both proko and vilppu simultaneously, it's astounding how different proko's approach to gesture is than vilppus.

Proko constantly says "MOTION NOT CONTOUR" but all his demo videos are him simplifying contours.... then you look at vilppu and you see him making these fluid lines that actually seem related to motion and realize how stiff proko's shit is

desu tho, proko's gesture is much easier for a beg to learn. I still really struggle to do gesture in the same manner as vilppu and this is my third week grinding it.

>>6396806
Soft shading/lighting with fewer steps. Gotta tweak the airbrush settings because default airbrush settings are often bad. If you use CSP, consider getting the “airy airbrush” tool. You can get similar results blocking in color on a higher layer then using a soft eraser, but a good airbrush will do that all on its own. Imo, it’s an essential tool for ani semi-realistic soft shading.

>>6477580
I just canceled my sub.

I really disliked the format. Also having drawn for a few years I knew most of the intro classes already but the big issue is there’s lots and lots of droning on and on about nothing and tons of empty space.

Basically they try to pace it like a real life class, but without any time for you to actually work. As a result most instructors just talk for 4 hours about things that could easily be condensed down to like a 10 minute YouTube video.

It’s just not worth the money imo. Some of the classes themselves are fine and the instructors are telling you correct information. It’s just painfully padded out to increase the video times and there’s very little there you wouldn’t find on YouTube for free.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6477580
>>6477593
This. In a 10 hour course you will have 9 hours of filler. The only good courses are the Vilppu and Steve Huston Courses.

The owner, Joshua Jacobo, said in an interview he doesn't allow his teachers to edit any of their classes, because he wants the students to see that the "teachers also make mistakes", but this results in an endless droning on and rambling about nothingness. It's especially bad when they start demoing, because they'll just stop talking and draw.

Get the Vilppu course, then bail.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6469277
Tattooer here. I do not consider myself an artist. Actually, according to one of my mentors who has been in the industry for almost 30 years, tattoing started to tear off of its origins and traditions around the time some tattooers started calling themselves tattoo "artists".
I feel very sorry for those who have experienced the elders' gatekeeping. I have been incredibly blessed by not one but four ridiculous old monsters who have been tattooing for almost, and in one case, for a longer time than I have been alive, and they have been very generous and kind with their knowledge, experience and wisdom, so just so you know, people like that exist too. But to those who are just squeezed, juiced, used and thrown away, please don't get discouraged. Dickheads are found in every industry, and unfortunately not only those of sound mind do tattoos or get them. If you enjoy and respect tattooing, you are able to gain a foothold in it, and the more effort you put into it, the more you get out of it, always.
To everyone who wants to get into tattoing, I advise to seek out the roots of the craft, learn traditional artforms, be it western guache-illustrations, middle-eastern mural patterns or tibethan thangka painting, copy and master the traditional methods of tattoo designing, learn to value good foundations and technicality, and always, always be humble. If you manage to establish a decent portfolio, and do an as exhausting research on the history of the industry as you can, you will be miles ahead of the average apprentice (that I have met). My apprenticeship has started very shoddily as well, and I was almost completelt crushed by my first studio, but holding on was without a doubt worth it, and I would gladly undergo the 6 (sometimes 7) days of ridiculous 8-12 hours a day unpaid labor and myriads of favours once again to be where I am. Finishing a work you can be proud of is intoxicating.
I wish all you the best, please enjoy the journey as much as you can.

>>6473739

Not the same person but these are good questions.

Start by building a portfolio with drawings, paintings, different styles etc. go to shops get tattooed by different artists always helps (especially the place you'd want to apprentice). don't bother with fake skin or machines if you want to apprentice, just wait until you get the apprenticeship. Ask in person and bring a physical portfolio, tends to help with older people that might be up to mentor.

If you want to learn yourself there's a lot of info but sorting it out and making sure you get the right information can be difficult. I wouldn't recommend not having a mentor but it's absolutely doable. Make sure your sanitation practice is incredibly on point. Also you most likely will be worse for longer and pick up more than a few bad habits. Never buy the machines they sell on amazon.

>>6473739
Bit late to the response, sorry.

As much as it sucks to say, instagram (and twitter depending if you're in the US) is king for tattoos, so build a good portfolio of flash on there. Like 20 pieces minimum. Just digital is usually fine unless it's an oldschool shop, in which case, print em onto a3.

I got an apprenticeship, but basically taught myself how to tattoo, and went to artists I loved and asked them to run me through what they are doing when they did my pieces.

Practice on yourself, fruit and fake skin to start, and I'd say a couple good mates who dont care if they're gonna get a shit tattoo helps a ton too.

Getting the apprenticeship is the hard part, after that, you get realistically endless opportunities to meet artists you like, and go learn from them. Most are happy to impart some wisdom if you're getting a tattoo and supporting them.

Tough the techniques that would fix your personalities permanently take too long to explain and apply, you can default to the Mind Trick, of which I should publish an article one of these days.

It's simple and it's something that everyone is familiar with, though nobody but me appears to have understood its nature.

Ever learned to ignore tickles? Stop shivering from cold? Stop sneezing?
It's all one single state of mind, and if you engage in it you're basically choking off some brain processes temporarily for so long as you maintain it.

Why am I mentioning this? Because another effect is that you cannot feel emotions in that state.

I tested many times, and I can guarantee it. If you also have the ability to trigger any emotion at will, you can also try and come to the same conclusion. They're mutually exclusive.
So whenever you start feeling panic attacks or other unnecessary feelings that lead to loss of control, you now know what to do.

>>6469409
I only bother with Patreon and Gumroad so

You have to skirt around Patreon's rules because the banks cucked them which means you're getting cucked too.
Also set up your patreon so that you're charging Patrons the moment they sign up a pledge. You'll end up getting a couple of people who will hop between different pledges so they can collect whatever you have and then leave so make that change in how you charge your Patrons first before anything else because Patreon for whatever reason doesn't have that set as the default
Cropping your images also helps with this but it also helps keep Patreon itself off your back. Because of Banks cucking them Patreon now has rules about what you can and cannot post on their site, so crop out the really bad stuff and only post those on your Discord instead

For Gumroad all I can say is that it's good passive income so long as you're actively advertising that you have one with stuff to sell on it. It doesn't have to be big things like long comics, some doodles and images with alts work too as well

Don't be discouraged when people inevitably leak your work. Sometimes you'll gain a few new followers who like it and will want to support you

>>6464068
Read how stable diffusion actually works. It basically trains the algorithm to denoise a generated noisy image over a number of iterations to produce an image (along with whatever NLP algorithm is used to interpret the initial prompt). Also it's unsupervised learning, meaning there is no real validation afterwards, it just returns after running.

What it means is that if the training images already have some proc generated watermark all over it, generated in a way that it couldn't easily be removed by existing watermark removal tools, than any generated images of that artist's artstyle (ie. generate xyz in the style of so and so) would try to include those watermarks as well and it would make it really obvious that it was AI generated because they'd likely be fucked up looking in ways a human could easily determine (ie. similar to how SD has no concept of how many fingers a hand has and constantly generates fucked up looking ones)

>>6464025
Retrained how?
Let me put it this way
1. Artist A posts a lot of public art, but all there art includes some watermark repeated, but altered in some semi random way based on a seed/key that only they have

2. This art is scraped and used as a training dataset for an art generation AI

3. Someone only enters the prompt "I want this image in artist A's style" and the AI creates an image

Now, because all of the artists images included that watermarking, the AI will naturally try to include something similar to it, but without knowing that initial seed/key the original artist will have an easy way of proving that this is a generated version, not authentic.

And even if someone altered the prompt to not include the watermark, and it manages to generates something that looks remotely convincing (although it's unclear if it could or how well it would look) given that all of the publicly available images include them, that's also a giveaway

Make sense

>>6477386
This is bad because it increases the likelihood that people will miss it, and if someone REALLY wants to remove your sig then they can still do so.
If you insist on trying to make it as "permanent" as possible, a way to do it is to put a cleanly-readable sig over something that's a bitch to smooth out, like on the border of 2 gradients or crossing past errant strands of hair.
The more out-of-the-way it is the worse you're making it, because smearing it with not-quite-right colors can be more easily passed off. Making it have a feathered border can also make this worse to remove.

But this is a big pain in the ass vs a bar at the top or bottom of the image (reminiscent of one part of a letterbox) that contains your info and probably the date or something too.

**Strive for quantity AND quality.**

Anime Studying:
>Copy anime references exactly and draw them from memory. Use illustrations, screenshots, anime figures, 3D models, etc.
>Don’t copy recklessly. Use construction, color theory, and other fundamental concepts to rehearse a drawing process that you can later easily manipulate for original artwork.
>Post all of your anime studies. Post even when you’re told not to. Create an art community that actually draws and improves together instead of just talking about it.
>Number your attempts and link to your previous posts.
>Critiquers should lead by example by posting their studies.

posts.com:
>>6465776
assistants tools usually take cpu cycles to keep calculating stuff even on idle, this may cause lag on bigger projects, also the farther the vanishing points the more resource it may use...

Using a image template (raster level) there is no thinking involve, so less prone in lagging another benefit is that as the template is just another layer I can apply all the functions available to layers (blending modes, stacking order, masking, etc.) I can't imagine making something like a comic strip in which every panel may have a different vanishing points from each other with assistants tools.
Ended up using this templates, https://www.davidrevoy.com/article814/perspective-grids-for-comics-in-krita
but I think I will make an 8k version.

Did I make myself understood?, I'm mentally drained kek

>>6467614
Done, yes, it is chalk from csp. From a quick test on krita it can be replicated using "chalk details" brush and playing around with pattern strength. For some reason this brush is much easier to give a seamless continuation using multiple overlapping strokes while having a nice line weight, probably because of the coarseness of the pattern.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6465902
I think you should trace real people and anime characters, and get a feel for the curves, anatomy and how they are normally shaped.
You have some idea on what to do, but you may over exxagerate some stuff to a point thing it may look wrong, tracing should help bring it back to normal levels.
The word tracing may sound icky, but it helped for me and made me see what i got wrong despite figure drawing and study constantly, tracing just made it click.

If it helps, make some notes; i made the hp bone too sharp, my toes have too much definition, my shoulders are not as slender. Do stuff like that and you'll get afeel for how it's meant to be.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6469437
you are drawing symbols. in other words, you are putting flat stickers of eyes and mouth on a template when you're supposed to draw things with volume and perspective in mind
for example, in a front shot, the eyes and mouth don't curve upward like that, they curve toward the face because they protrude off of it. you drew it as if you were looking from above although still wrong
my personal advice whould be to look into the planes of the face and features so you know how to apply perspective to them. believe it or not, although the average anime face looks fairly simple it still relies on understanding the structure of a real face to make it look cute

Make the application portion the highest priority for what you are doing and chose artist to study for that you feel confident that you will be able to learn from initially. posts.com: I decided to try drawing from memory and it's uhh... actually a lot better than I thought it would be. It's kinda fun to compare it to the original, seeing what I got wrong, what I completely forgot about, and what I actually paid enough attention to to remember. I feel like I'll be able to pay better attention to the image as a whole next time as well as filter out stuff that just wouldn't be helpful. Like you can see that I tried to draw the hair simplified but didn't remember it at all, and now that I look at how it actually was I could see myself simplifying it into 4-5 simple shapes if I were to do it again.

Keep the skin tone simple first, just work with 4.
1. Select the base flesh tone and fill body.
2. Select a lighter tone for highlights over softly.
3. Select a deeper tone for shadow areas, again softly apply.
4 Select a midway tone between the shadow and base tone to blend all.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6476412

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6476430
I see. But how do you know which color fits which shade of gray?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6476412

You need to be able to recognize "values" in a painting. This is the base of your painting, the building blocks, the sauce on the pizza. Colors are toppings, decoration, sprinkles of accent and emotion - but the base values need to be there.

Check out Airi Pan's Fool Proof Concept Art course. She explains it rather well in the first couple of videos, but it's better that you practice it 'cause it's kinda hard to wrap your head around.

If I had to summarize it, I'd say that you need to be able to identify large shapes in your painting and separate them into something comprehensible and appealing. One good practice exercise is to take a screenshot from a movie, turn it into grayscale, squint your eyes and try to identify the shapes using only three values (black, white and gray). Colors come after - shape language is more important. Some of the real pros forego the value construction altogether - but that's because they're pros and know it all by heart already, so they start with color straight away.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6470632
can't quite put my finger on it but it feels like she goes off-model for the last few frames

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6470632
the eyebrows arent in sync with the eyes hence the delayed action feeling

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6470632
refine the chin placement it follows a rigid pathing make it follow some sort of smooth arch it'll look more natural that way
the bangs have a nice delayed action to them good job : D
also i'd suggest drawing the ears as well even if they're just place-holders cause they'll help keep the head shap from warping with each succesive frame
hold the looking at camera frame for longer before transitioning into the forward leaning motion also make the head a bit farther back in that frame or push it slightly forward in the final pose cuz if you're leaning forward you bend forward slightly rather than rotation forward while being stuck in the same location
also do the eyes completely open first and add the blink after you've smoothened the movement
i get the vibe you're going for but i think you over-stepped in that bit
as is anime eyes are already notoriously difficult to place properly since their orientation depends on the camera angle rather than some defined points in space

you have long way to grow young grass-hopper
