>>6470942
>>6471023
>>6471012

I make 95K a year doing storyboards in the US.

You have to stay within the confines of the script, there are times when you can make some changes but you have to pitch it to your superiors so it goes you > director > supervising director > showrunner/execs. If your change makes it all the way through that multiple times it probably will stay in through the final.

We do a lot of previs here in the US so shot composition, and fight choreography. but it depends. A lot of board artists in the US like to do almost key animation because there isn't a huge budget for retake animation.

I will say that you don't HAVE to be a super good draftsman to be a great board artist. But if you can combine good drawing skills with a rudimentary level of knowledge of animation and shot composition you will never be out of a job for more than months at a time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6471069
do you have a lot of free time outside of work to make comics / personal projects? How busy are you when you are actually in the office? (like, how reasonable are the deadlines?)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6471081

Yes and No.

Storyboarding is not a 40-hour-a-week job in the sense that. It requires such a command of so many different skills some of which have nothing to do with drawing; Time Management, Shot Comp, Animation, and Draftsmanship hell if your gonna make your storyboards you need to have editing know-how. So realistically you're gonna be working 50-70 hour weeks.

But there's a catch. A good one I might add. My schedule is roughly 10-11 weeks per episode. We turn things in and have to wait a week or two for notes and this process happens about 3 times after that 11-week deadline. So sometimes we are sitting on our hands or helping other teams on their episodes.

So if you make sure to hone your time management skills you can have a bunch of free time. But when we are working it's intense, but it's kind of made up for on the back end.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6471102
It's okay man, I lurk here from time to time but I only answer questions that I view as sincere. So don't worry about it.

I don't feel trapped at all, storyboarding exposes you to so much that when you're doing it you can't help but improve. I'm only a few years in but I know people that maintain a comic and board. The thing is that there are a lot of opportunities to move up (some people get in through nepotism, but not all), and with moving up comes a significant pay bump. I'm talking about being a Director (120-195K a year), but it also comes with more responsibilities and that means those 50+ hour weeks just went to 80+ hour weeks and on top of that YOU are responsible for how the animatic turns out, so more stress too.

I know people who just hit that 10-year mark, they are all mostly directors by then, and if they aren't they are just board artists that are paid well because they want to protect their time because they want to do what you wanna do. It's a balancing act, no one can tell you what to do. But the only way you'll know is if you commit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6473076

I started as a revisionist, I didn't finish school. I got more and more opportunities as time went on. Like I said above, there's no correct answer besides actual boarding. I know it's kind of a meme but everyone's path is different and you will never know until you commit to a path of action. I'll say this about portfolios, everyone says you should have 2-3 different pieces with action and drama, etc. But that's not necessarily true. I got hired off of a few action poses and one board. So In my experience, I would say focus on making boards and composition but also focus on life drawing and figure drawing, I mean actually sit down and work through the phases, lay in, contour, values, and finishing. A few hours a day thumbnailing for boards, and a few hours a day life drawing will take you insanely far. By the time you get around to finishing a board you will be better than you were. And on top of that if you always thumbnailing you will have a bunch of thumbs that you can draw upon to make into full boards in the future if you want to. it's a win-win. Also, learn Storyboard Pro as well as you can in school if you have access to it.

posts.sub: Schizo take on social media feedback
posts.com:
So I just post stuff I've occasionally drawn on insta for the sake of it - who knows maybe it hits the right spot for someone else. I also follow a few people whose style and art I really like and sometimes express it through an appreciative comment, a share and sometimes join their art contests. Couple of them are big-ish i.e. 10k+ follows or something and they seemed to welcome this feedback to the point where they follow me back, "like" my work and sometimes we have a chat about the community and art or whatever. All cool. Nice.

The issue begins when I start getting praise comments/feedback from them. Of course feedback is nice, sure. Everyone likes getting that nice uplifting comment. But I really value genuine feedback.

Recently I've come to think the positive feedback/messages I get from those artists are just forced back scratching with no value. I may have no following and thus they probably try to support, but this support sounds fake to the point where it feels condescending.

Like, you don't give a shit about my art, why pretend? I don't draw things you care about. I'm no striving artist. I'm just an average joe pinup animeshit artist to pass my time.

I guess you want to get it off your chest that you've "now supported me back" since I went up your ass, but now it has an opposite effect. I don't believe anything they say anymore. It instead hurts because in the beginning I thought shit was genuine and I had actual artists liking my work. I gave up and disabled comments/shares. I'd rather get nothing over bs.

So did I hit a shit community corner where children are indoctrinated to hugbox or is this the norm I'm too stupid to understand?

>>6462462
It depends on the amount of control you have, not on the medium. With photoshop, you are using the machine as a tool while doing the bulk of the work yourself. It's just another form of a brush, essentially. With SD, the only thing you control is the prompt you type but you have little control over the actual output besides choosing one that's "good enough". That's why copyright claims over ai artwork keep getting denied on the basis of not having been made by a human and that's also why SD can produce "art" even if you type nothing.

Obviously things get more complicated with people using ai as only part of their work (like for a background) but let's be real, most proompters are interested in quick results, they're not gonna bother with anything non-ai generated anyway

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6474936
It's just part of a small farewell present for a tank commander, commanding a mine flail called 'Keiler', which is German for male wild boar. He is also a hunter and comes from an area renowned for its woods and hills which were also painted by Casper David Friedrich a lot. I told the AI to create the painting in CDF's style for which the painting is much too bright and not detailed enough but I was still relatively satisfied with the result. It was definitely the best result of at least a dozen generations.

The canvas will probably end up hanging in his new office. Adding structure to it seemed like an easy way to fool most people who don't know anything about painting and only visit his office briefly into thinking this was actually painted by hand. I feel like I would be somewhat impressed to see something like this hanging in someone's office in my line of work.

People usually don't put too much effort or money into presents like these but I feel like it's more original than a group photo or a piece of shrapnel signed by the whole platoon. In the end it will have cost me around 40 euros and maybe 3 hours of work which seems reasonable.

Why don't you commission an actual fucking oil painting of this image, having the artist change it in any way you desire, maybe even to the point where it doesn't look like soulless twitter funko pop shit? ANY (male) art student in your area is going to be able to make something like this except better, for $3-400 easily, eagerly.
This image will always look digital, no matter what you do to it, even assuming a perfect print, which there won't be, because it's AI-generated sRGB. You also misunderstand how varnish works. Varnish settles. The reason paintings are bumpy is because of the paint, not the varnish. A brush will add "grain" to it, maybe, but it will still settle onto the even surface of the print in an even way, unless you flash cure it with UV or something, and even then, there won't be enough varnish. You can't just dump a centimeter thick layer on it, it will never cure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This has to be a bait thread, it's so fucking obtuse and I'm going to fall for it, right now.

OP posted a bunch of indie titles, and indie devs just need to be able to scribble their ideas on paper, list what they want, and have artists able to translate that into the greatest factor in what makes a game actually stand out visually: consistency, art direction, and most of all intuitive utility. A good game needs the player to be able to easily recognize interactables and landmarks in order to progress or complete a gameplay loop.

For a pro artist who's been hired for legit concept art for AAA titles that typically go for realism and fidelity in graphics, they need loomis, they need grind fundies, they need talent and skill. They need to put those things into practice for the intensive graphics the modelers are working with to translate into the game. they need to impress suits most of all for the money, who are just in it for the business, not because they even play video games. It's why you get trends like brown and bloom and filters that make everything look the same and people don't like it because nothing actually stands out. Feel pretty bad for them, proompters actually will take their jobs in their field when they put in a lot of work for the goal.

It's also why indie titles tend to have a longer shelf life: the more effort you spend on polygons, complex lighting and realism, the more a game ages as technology surpasses what was before possible in processing graphics. Art direction > Graphical fidelity.

OP , have you ever played a videogame?
In drawing , the visuals are the main and only component, you can't get away with bad visuals because visuals are the whole thing.
In videogames , the gameplay is the main component and other aspects serve it, artstyle (aka. graphics), audio (sounds/music) , etc.

In a videogame you can get away with a simple relatively meh artstyle provided it helps or at the very least does not hinder gameplay. Something like readability is usually more important than just looking nice but in an actual fight you cannot tell what the fuck is going on (unless the poor visibility is intentional, and the dev knows how to balance around it). This is because people are focues on the gameplay rather than the visuals.

For example in Among Us (Game where you have to find who is the murderer,who called "the impostor"):
-You can tell who is who if you just look at the color unless you are colorblind
(Among Us isnt very fast paced game so sillouettes being exactly the same is not a big problem and might help the game's "simplistic" look (not sure about this), colorblindness might be a problem , not sure how they tackle it (note that in the actual game you see the username above their heads , not color) )
-You can eazily differentiate them from the map

Minecraft (A 3 Dimensional block building game):

-You can tell what material is what (like telling water and lava apart)
-You can tell where a block begins and ends (if there are neighbouring blocks you might not be able to tell where it ends exactly (eg. grass blocks) ,but every block having a well defined border would look kinda ugly)
-You can tell mobs apart from eachother
-You can tell items apart from eachother (for the most part, if not , texture packs are your friend)
-Artstyle is stuff being made out of smaller blocks , realistic mobs and players living in a block world would look weird... as if they don't follow the unspoken rule of the game.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6475952
Find some proportion diagrams, look at them, copy them, roughly sketch the diagrams from memory, check them. Keep it in mind when you start drawing figures from life or reference, and when you draw poses from imagination.
All that said, you can always use reference. Keep studying anatomy, perspective, proportion, etc as you draw, but don't think you need to be a master of everything before you finally start drawing what you want to draw; don't think you need to reach the magical point of "everything I draw is entirely from my mind" before you start producing the art you want to produce. Never be afraid to use references, especially with all the libraries of reference photos out there, pose dolls/software, your own body and camera, etc etc., but you'll find that the more you draw, the less you'll have to rely on references as starting points and the more you'll use them as helpers or checks.

posts.com:
Its important you do fun stuff too, op. Don't get too focused on grinding fundamentals...especially when its such a specific thing as these shapes you're doing. Practice but also apply in equal amounts. You gotta remember why you do it in the first place.

I learned a lot about form by doing drawings of random objects on my desk. Make sure that you're drawing from life. Its important you see things in 3d and then mentally convert them to the 2d plane of the paper, rather than only copying stuff out of Vilppu's book. Copy also and read what he says and all that... but draw from life especially, I say.

Wish you luck, dude.

>>6476045
Ugh. I honestly think you should ignore all these teachers who think you should be a human graphics card. Computers have had a baleful influence on art instruction, in that people look at wireframes and 3D models and think the goal is for you to be able to draw complex 3D constructions in violent perspective from any point of view. It's absurd. What's the point, anyway?
In most great figurative art of the past, perspective in the figures is not emphasized, because perspective entails distortion that, in depictions of the human figure, isn't pleasing to the eye. Art instruction books of the past tended to focus on the characteristic forms of the head, torso, limbs, etc. in repose and in action. You can learn this without turning everything into boxes and wireframes.
Yes, you should know the fundamentals of perspective (not difficult, read "Perspective Made Easy"). And yes, it is useful to draw cross-contours or think of cylinders and planes when foreshortening a limb, but turning this type of construction into a quasi-religion, as is being done here, is insane.
A useful and practical way of learning to draw, say, a thigh from the side view:
1. The attachment of the thigh to the trunk is higher in front than behind. So, too is the attachment of thigh to knee.
2. The front line is a gentle, convex curve with its peak closer to the top than the bottom, and inclined so the top is slightly forward in relation to the bottom. It runs from a little below the front pelvic point above, to just above the knee cap.
3. The back line is nearly straight from its start below the buttocks to its end just below the back of the knee. However, the upper two-thirds of this line bulges in a very subtle, convex curve.
And so on. Curved lines, straight lines and angles. If you can write the letter C, you can draw a curved line. Now think about the characteristics of the curve you are studying -- how it is angled, where it peaks, how gentle or violent the curvature.

I think 600 likes for 2k is a very good amount. Theres people with 10k who get less than that.
The usual tips are the same as always, drawing OCs from larger users, try nsfw, fotm, keep posting a lot and such. You are already improving as you keep drawing and posting new content, your followers notice that.

I think the luck factor is very important. Being in the right spot at the right time. How do RTs from big accounts work for you? Do they get lots of likes/follows? If thats so, aim for that.

Me personally cant grow by my own anymore as Im shadowbanned. I draw nsfw, not hardcore stuff though, just nudes. Everytime I post something new, my tweet gets hidden for at least 12 hours. It isnt showing in the search option, not by keywords, neither tags. I rely just on my own followers and luck. And even my own followers dont see my posts most of the time. I have 3k, but only getting 30 likes or so because of this. The moment another account RTs me, I can reach 3k likes. Thats really awful and discouraging.

I wish there were other places for promote yourself instead of depending 100% on that.

>>6451775
When Im first sketching a scene it looks kinda similar, its my style. But its been months since my last big draw. Think that I sculpt with my pen in ZBrush, so Im basically drawing in 3D, rotating 360º my figures and adjusting them on every angle, they need to look fine.

Creating 3D scenes instead of 2D, allows me to do many other things, like rotating over the scene, animating, scaling specific parts, changing the pose or working with cloth/fluid physics.

But the main reason for using them in interactive scenes inside Unreal is for example changing their clothes with particle effects, different hairstyles, or anything you can imagine inside a videogame.
Im still polishing my scenes but Im planning to make them downloadable with small minigames and such

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6469580
That's pretty much the sentiment of most people who actually start to get closer to achieving "the dream" of being a published mangaka. It's so obtuse and difficult, the odds are stacked so hard against you that it legitimately starts to seem less and less ridiculous to just try and make your way in the busted ass western comic scene instead. The manga industry is incredibly competitive, it's a complete pipedream even for the natives, and you have all the additional handicaps that come with trying to learn a language and then do business in a foreign country (a notoriously bureaucracy-nightmare of a country at that) that treats foreigners as odd curiosities, and not only that but compete with the famously incredibly hard working natives to write stories that will capture THEIR local market, a market you almost certainly don't quite realize how different it is in terms of what appeals to and interests them in an industry that even within their work-yourself-to-death culture is considered to be one of the harsher vocations.
To get to the point, the closer to get the more you realize that you don't actually want to get it, and that you were probably better off where you were.

>>6469461
i studied japanese two years ago so maybe i can give some useful advice

depending on how good you want to be and the time you want it to take will determine how much time you want to put in
>about 6-8 hours a day to get good in 3-5 years
>about 4-6 hours a day to get good in over 5 years
>under 6 hours a day to get good in about 10 years
we're not talking being fluent, we're just talking about being good enough to have conversations without constantly stuttering and being able to understand most conversations that aren't too technical

the second year of studying made me realize the sheer amount of effort and work required in order to get good at japanese
i was pulling 6-8 hour workdays, grinding anki cards, and making sure i was good on my Kanji strokes and despite all of this, i still ended up with an elementary understanding of Japanese
sure, i can watch anime without subtitles but i miss about 70% of what is being said and can only understand simple phrases and conversations yet i felt like i studied so damn much

if you still think you want to pursue it, i can give more detailed advice on what traps to avoid and what study materials are actually useful but i'd say to study it because you enjoy it not because you see yourself in a year or so being good at it because it's honestly going to take years just like with drawing
basically imagine the skill of drawing and how long it takes to get good and that's similar to how japanese is as well but it's a damn fun language to learn if you're up for it so i'd say to continue studying it just for that aspect but don't expect to get "good" in a year or so because it's just not that type of language

Personally, this was what gave me a foundational knowledge in Japanese to be able to study it from books effectively. Without Trombley-sama, I would've quit Japanese since I fell for a few traps that demotivated me previously. (Similar to drawing.)

https://a.co/d/3UCv3sy
>Literally the only book you need for Japanese grammar
>You can get more advanced but honestly that's up to you and not entirely necessary

https://apps.ankiweb.net/
https://ankiweb.net/shared/decks/japanese
>First is a link to download anki and second is a link of different japanese decks
>Here are some recommended decks
https://ankiweb.net/shared/info/2141233552
https://ankiweb.net/shared/info/1194221613
https://ankiweb.net/shared/info/266084933
>That last one is Kanji and will be very hard to learn so leave it for when you're ready
>You'll honestly know what level you're at and which ones you can study by the time you finished Japanese from Zero and gone through a bit of the Grammar book

You don't have to do it incrementally. If you get bored of Trombley (Japanese from Zero), you can try doing Grammar for a while or Kanji and then switching around to make it more exciting for you. Probably the best piece of advice I can give you though is to constantly do what it was that made you want to study it in the first place. The reason I stopped studying was because I stopped watching Anime and therefore lost my purpose to learn Japanese. It's a long journey so make sure you have a definite purpose for studying.
TRAPS TO AVOID:
>Reddit and their HORRIBLE advice
>Remembering the Kanji by Heisig
>Anything Abroad in Japan says to do
>Studying the Kanji in isolation
>Relying on Kana too much

Yea but I think it was mostly a waste of time. I'm very particular about how I study so it was natural for me to create my own decks that I thought were better than the ones online but in hindsight, I should've been "just studying" rather than doing that shit.

For Anki, I'd say go for both at the same time. It's going to be hard at first but your brain will eventually pick up on the patterns and you'll find yourself using it in sentences subconsciously. I only realize it because I would say certain phrases in the exact same tone and speed that the girl/guy says them in the Anki deck. Luckily, people have already done the hard work for you and you just need to find the good decks. For me, they were the Core 2000 decks on that shared Anki link I have there.

Also, I find that I cannot learn by studying one thing at a time. I tend to jump around a lot. This is important since you can get stuck on Anki decks for 6 months and get tired of Japanese so make sure to switch it up when you start to get tired.

I'm not trying to dissuade anyone from studying it but I was fucking obsessive with learning Japanese and I still didn't get to the level I wanted to reach which is why I always tell people to really consider it because this isn't something you're going to do in 1-2 years and be done with it, it's going to take a very long time.

>>6471078
i'm 6469610. I'm sorry to hear you got burned out on kanji. RTK sucks, kanji out of context sucks, bruteforce kanji sucks.

Kanji actually make a good deal of sense if you study kanji etymology. Kanji meanings relate to the components used to draw the character, sometimes it's only a small hint but sometimes it explains everything. The etymology also explain how the components gained their meaning; important because the components used to write a character underwent transformation and stylization.

Kanji having multiple meanings is in most cases a derived meaning from an earlier meaning. I didn't know this until I got the Outlier Kanji Dictionary (a kanji etymology dictionary).

For example, the kanji 解 originally means "to dismember an ox." The modern meanings derive from that to mean:
-> to dissolve, solve, unravel
-------> to untie, undo
-------> explanation, understanding

If you remember the logic and flow of the meanings it's not so bad.

>>6471073
I highly recommend you get the Outlier Kanji Dictionary.
You can probably learn kanji like I'm doing it now. Pick words that you understand well in spoken Japanese but don't know how to read. Look up the word in the Outlier dictionary, understand the kanji used with it, and make a card for the word containing the kanji in an anki deck. Start with learning simple 1-kanji verbs/nouns. Or learn the Grade 1 kanji first using this method because you are bound to have words to use for all of them.

When you are reading books, you can also do the same with words you want to remember the kanji for.

You will need to push at the beginning to understand how kanji work. And when you want to really commit a kanji to memory, you need to repeat the process I outlined above. But you are encoding the kanji way more strongly than most people as a result. Remembering becomes the easy part.

Since most words you end up studying are kanji compounds, you have two chances that at least one of the kanji make a lot of sense.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Study light/shadow, do the usual meme with shading balls and shit, learn anatomy so you know which parts of the body are shaded when the light hits from a certain direction, paint skin hit by light color A, skin in shadow color B, use soft edge brush to blend the transition.
For shit like the dress and its folds as well as the back jewelry, same deal. Do a lot of cloth and material studies so you know which materials will have softer or rougher shadows, and how to light cloth folds.

Rendering is so obscenely complicated that the artists who have good rendering skills are almost always shit at actually drawing, hence the existence of rendermonkeys and

The fact is, while you spend 16 hours painting a folds, ALL of your other knowledge is deteriorating, your anatomy knowledge and draftsmanship skills are literally disappearing as you do your day long painting.

This is why people who did not study as children and teens can never really make it, your brain just doesn't remember that stuff as well, someone who drew since they were 12 can afford to take days off or spend days painting complex fold structure since their other knowledge is second nature. Meanwhile yours is artificial and constantly slipping away unless you everything grind all the time.

>>6474841
>but that wasted time definitely won't make you worse at it.
It's a simple case of use it or lose it. Putting dozens of hours into a painting (as one does) is as helpful for your other fundamentals as laying in bed doing nothing at all. I'm not saying that rendering magically makes you bad, just that spending 12 hours on a painting is as good for your draftsmanship as not doing any art at all. It's nearly the same as if you spent your day playing video games or jacking off. People who got into art young don't have that problem because it's all second nature to them anyway, they can only go forward because those neural pathways that relate to art are incredibly strong.

This is very easy to understand if you have any skill you acquired as a child. For me it's the violin. I can play very very well and even if I go long periods without practicing I can pick up where I left off. I literally cannot forget how to play well, unless of course I get a stroke or something. Also the same with English (I'm ESL in a third world shithole), I always mogged everyone in all my English classes because I learned English as a kid, no matter how hard everyone else tried I would just be better without having to put in any effort. With art, however, I'm that kid who tries super hard to speak English and gets mogged by others who just had the opportunity to learn when their XP multiplier was at its highest.

I had this realization recently, there are things that I learned as a child that I just am good at. Then there's drawing which I got into at 21 (23 now) and its impossibly difficult to learn.

OK, go ask the ten million or so Americans/Canadian immigrants that moved there since they were 10 years old, that are not Mexican ghetto or 1920s Italian neighbourhood inhabitants or CCP spies, how well they can still speak their native languages as an adult. The answer might surprise you: They fucking can't. If you will forget your native language, the first thing ever put into your brain, that you are biologically hardwired to learn immediately and remember permanently as a strict necessity for your survival, then you will forget how to fucking draw as well. End of story. There is no such thing as childhood memory. You simply feel like things took longer to forget because you had lived a shorter amount of time, therefore things were "remembered" for a greater proportion of your lifetime, relatively.
The age where learning becomes more difficult starts in your 50s if you're unhealthy or have bad genetics(see: how old you look compared to your peers), and is a slow process that unfolds over your 60s and 70s until you die. There are no things you learned as a child that you are just as good at. There are no things a child can do better than an adult. There are things a high IQ person can do better than a low IQ person, and this applies to high IQ children vs low IQ adults, and that's it.

posts.com:
The general thread for Manga / manga-styled comic-making, manga-style illustration and related comic work.

Support each other and talk about your work or the work of others that excites you. Inking, character design, paneling / layout, writing, planning, and other discussions are all welcome.
Post resources, questions, in-progress pages, breakdowns of other works, etc. If a work is not yours, credit the maker (unless it's fucking obvious like a full page of One Piece or something).
Thanks to everyone for making /mmg/ a level-headed and helpful place. Remember, drawing and making comics and manga are difficult endeavors, and we're all in this struggle together.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Some western / indie publishers of Manga:

Saturday AM ( https://www.saturday-am.com/ )
> Digital indie magazine, seems to be on the up-and-up
> Open submissions for long-form series; also distributes series currently being published elsewhere.
> Regularly publishes one-shots, making it a good potential outlet for already-finished work.

Noir Caesar ( https://www.noircaesar.com/ )
> Focuses on black (specifically African-American) content, but seems willing to publish anyone good enough.
> Seemingly series-based only.
> No "magazine" style updates; series are updated on their own schedule.
> Seems less regular than Saturday AM, but also seems larger in terms of readership.

Oni Press ( https://onipress.com/ )
> Technically indie, but at this point large enough by comic standards to be mentioned in the same breath as other publishers.

Antarctic Press ( https://antarctic-press.myshopify.com/ )
> Longtime large-indie publisher of OEL / manga-esque books.
> Seemingly taking submissions at present if http://www.antarctic-press.com/html/submissions.php is anything to go on.

Yen Press ( https://yenpress.com/ )
> Started out as a small indie publisher of original / Korean material, and has grown reasonably popular since.
> As of 2016, it is also one of the western arms of the Kadokawa Corporation, with Kadokawa owning a 51% stake.
> Editorial inquiries can apparently be sent to yenpress@yenpress.com, however, they apparently are not open to new submissions at this time.

Viz Media / Viz Originals ( https://www.viz.com/originals )
> *The* western manga publisher.
> Currently in the exploratory stages of setting up an English label.
> Submissions are open and several books have been announced. However, progress on the label seems to be moving very slowly.
> Still might be worth a shot anyway.

Shrine Comics ( https://shrinecomics.com/ )
> Small indie manga publisher
> Seemingly attempting to make the transition to physical volumes
> Allows crossposting to other sites

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6449929
It's very good for making manga (page by page format) and webtoons (scrolling format).
Pretty much every professional that makes manga digitally uses it.
It has all the tools you need and the free assets store has a ton of stuff to make the creation process even easier like premade speech bubbles, manga backgrounds, effects brushes, 3d models and so on.
My only gripe with clipstudio is that the lettering system is so barebones that it hurts.
It gets the job done but it does feel very clunky doing your lettering in clipstudio.
I've only made comics in paint tool sai before and compared to that clipstudio is so much better.
Also there's a ton of tutorials on the creation process both official and by fans on youtube.
Just buy it on a sale.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6454002
I have only looked at the chapters so I can't comment on the writing.

I really like the composition and artstyle even though it's pretty simple and scratchy.
It seems to fit the atmosphere quite well.

You should really think about using proper speechbubbles or if you want to keep the uniqe speechbubbles you currently use then please use a better font.
Your current font makes it look like those old scanlations of manga.
Lettering is just as important as art and composition.
Blambot.com has a lot of free and good looking comic fonts for dialogue and effects. Blambot even lets you use these fonts commercially for prints and stuff if you're an indie artist.

I can also see you're structuring the panels like a manga or comic page.
You don't have to do this on webtoon because of the infinite scrolling webtoons have.
Take advantage of this feature and give your panels more breathing room and space between each other.
It feels very crammed and overwhelming as it currently is. Remember, there are no pages on webtoons. There's just one very long page pretty much.
Look at how popular webtoons are placing their panels.
You can do a lot of unique and fun paneling on webtoon that you couldn't do with a traditional page-to-page layout.

Also think about using more differently shaped panels.
It's fine as it is right now but it might become boring or samey seeing the same rectangle panels as you create more chapters.


Overall it looks good and promising. Godspeed anon!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6454002
I read the full thing. I though it was great, main thing I dislike is the dialogue. You should change the font, have speech bubbles, and also just go over everything to remove unnecessary lines, and edit forced lines. I'm also working on a comic, and it's definitely a challenge to make dialogue seem natural and not cringe-inducing. Try and act out the interaction in your head, and ask yourself if it would be like that in a real life interaction. Also keep in the mind that the character's personality plays a role in each interaction (If you haven't done this already, you should write down a document for yourself that includes your character's personality, motivations, fears, etc..) And another thing to keep in mind is that not everything has to be vocalized.

I found it weird how this main character knows English well when she was abandoned as a little kid, I think she should be more mute (Or maybe you could make her dialogue have a purposefully limited choice of words.) And like the other anon said, it should be explained how she built an entire house by herself, knows how to cook, and how she has money.

Overall I thought this was pretty cool and I'm looking forward to your revisions and more chapters.

oof I totally know how you feel anon.
It's even worse when you have a hairstyle that's asymmetrical and you want to show it from both sides.
I've seen some artists just flip the hair depending on the angle to always show the good side but I feel like an idiot whenever I do that.
I hate creating inconsistencies, especially with something as small as hairstyles.
I haven't shied away from drawing my characters at certain angles but sometimes the hairstyle looks natural and other times it looks like dogshit.

But recently I've started constructing my hairstyles from the ground up like you would with a body instead of slapping shapes onto them until it looks good.
I've found that it's much easier to draw hairstyles at multiple angles that way.
Still not completely satisified but I'm getting there.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6457557
Writing is just like drawing. Your first work will be complete garbage.
For some of the anons in this thread it might be their very first attempt at creating a comic.
Even if you know what makes a great comic great, actually putting in the time and making these ideas a reality is a different beast and incredibly humbling.
Playing it safe and creating something somewhat generic is way better for learning story writing, character writing, dialogue, pacing, paneling and so on instead of trying to make your magnum-opus on your first try.
They're doing their steps towards becoming better artists and writers by just creating something even if it's garbage and learning from it (hopefully).
You don't believe that all the successful comic-artists hit gold with their very first comic(s), do you?

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6457614
>asymmetrical and you want to show it from both sides.
Yup that's one of my problems alright, and I also feel like an idiot when I do the magic side flip. That pic says it all.
My particular design isn't completely unrealistic so it is by all means possible to convincingly draw it from all angles, but it's not only time consuming but just a touch beyond my skill set. I'm really studying the shape of skulls and the way locks of hair grow out of them, but then I also have to convert that to stylized shapes that suit my chosen style. Figure out what liberties I should take with shape placement at awkward angles so it doesn't look goofy. And then I'll have to be consistent with it every goddamn time. Bodies and clothing inconsistencies can be forgiven but when a characters head looks off, everyone can immediately tell something is off. I'm always amazed how mangaka keep their art so crisp for 10+ years at a time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Big hurdle for me was learning to accept that my characters are going to resemble some other character, somewhere. Indeed. And that's without even mentioning that these are the cream of the crop. Western comics have a bad habit of feeling incredibly immaturely created, not just in the sense of having very simple themes, but that their writers seem to have pretty surface level grasps on a lot of concepts. In fact, surface level is a good term for it. Now, I'm probably a lot more anti-anime and anti-manga than most people in this thread - I generally despise the modern state of them and think they've flanderized themselves into oblivion - but one thing I can't deny is that there are those stories that have that 'understanding' in them only a writer with deeper thoughts can have. That medium awareness that second order thinking that's usually reserved for non-comic mediums in western media.

This probably comes from the fact most comic writers don't own their properties and kind of get handed them offhand with significant limitations on what they must and must not do.

Also sometimes this shit happens.

>>6471769
I don't particularly care about gating an art form by whether or not you know the name of some half dozen artists involved in it, but I will say that comic book fans are more likely than almost any other consumer to specify they like a specific artist or writer, rather than liking a title. This is partially owed to the frequent reboots / Crisis events making a unified canon nonexistent, but more importantly, the long term serialization meaning that the character is heavily dependant on the writer and artist. Have a serious conversation with comic book fans about their favorite superhero or comic run and they'll probably go ''[This character], but only when written by Alan Moore''.

I do specify comic book FANS here, not the average consumer, because the average Marvel or DC consumer doesn't even read comic books, let alone have favorite runs. Making something appealing to the masses is an entirely different deal than making something good enough to have fans.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6476016
I'm not sure that there is any comprehensive resource on just "making manga", in the same way that there isn't one on making movies or making animations. There's too many elements to really cover, and most elements are creative, not technical, meaning there isn't a single "right" way to do it, merely wrong ways. The best way to learn is to make your own things and analyze manga you like, applying what you observe in your own stuff as immediately as you can. That's how the pros learnt, by copying the mangaka that they grew up on and branching off from that.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6477196
>What do you do if everyones already done all your ideas
There's no such thing as an idea that hasn't been thought of. There are an almost infinite number of ways to do an idea, the vast majority of which haven't been done, and many of which could only be done by someone like you. Some of them are even good.

>What do you do if you have an idea but don't know how to pad it out to be longer than a single volume?
Make it a single volume, or mix it in with other ideas. If an idea only works in a vacuum with itself, then it's not a good idea.

Ultimately, such a vague question is hard to answer in a way that you want to hear.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6476971
Here's my process:
>draw page, ink page
>scan page
>clip studio paint
>convert brightness to opacity to extract line art
>make layer below this, fill in greys here, screentone aswell if I want
it's actually pretty simple ngl. Just make sure your original linework is clean af

>>6463841
I got in the industry by founding my own gaming company with colleagues and being employed there with an artist role. So not really your typical way of getting into the industry, but definitely one with the brightest future I would say. Would recommend over chasing jobs and clients your whole career.
But if you want to get into the industry, don't send the same portfolio to dozens of clients. Tailor it to their needs, show them that you want to do the "dirty" jobs as well. For example, if you want to do concept art, don't just put up flashy images of soldiers (they got enough people who want to do that) but rather lots of concepts for mundane objects that will fill their game world. But really, it depends on what kind of industry you want to get into

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6469065
It depends on your current artistic ability, the book, and your goals. There is no best way. The whole idea is figuring out how to change the way you make art for the better. That vision you have of what that means is an important part of this.

For studying figure drawing and "human anatomy," the entire goal is to flesh out your mental model of the human figure and to be able to draw upon that model (i.e. important details of the surface form and/or how muscles overlap or change from movement). You should probably copy (process drawings by copying them); doing so helps you flesh out your mental model. (Don't go overboard on your copies).

You then want to use that new detail in other contexts (drawing from imagination and drawing from reference). If you're at the level where you're making art on a frequent basis, then try to find ways to directly use it to inform your art. If you do not make use of what you learn in other contexts you are significantly less likely to remember it and use it. Your brain is designed to forget useless information and skills; if what you study from a book is not put to use it is just that, useless.

Forgetting is also common in the learning process and will vary depending on how much you already know. If you try to remember something you learned and forgot it, re-study it. If you try to remember something you learned and realized what you learned isn't in-depth or robust enough to be useful, you study it more. It is more important to become skilled in one thing to the point that it is actually useful rather than knowing not enough to be useful about a hundred things.

Don't let an art book consume you, this is the worst mistake to fall into. If all you're up to is reading it and copying from it, you're just pissing time and paper away. Remember that it is just a part of a reasonable artistic training regimen.

I haven't read every manga ever, but from the ones I've read Vagabond really stands out in terms of artistic quality and technique. It's consistent, the characters are distinctive without relying on over-the-top stylization, it uses abstraction at parts very successfully and sparingly. Humans look like humans and action scene movements look reasonable.

Yokohama Kaidashi Kikou for scenery porn gets a pass. I thought Oyasumi Punpun used the media of comics really cleverly at parts. BLAME! is distinctive, and even though it's rather jank at parts I think it makes up for that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Game design IS an art form.

Back in the stone ages of computing,my roommate and I would deathmatch in a map that he created and filled with hidey holes and deathtraps, and I had to find him and lay ambushes of my own. I tried making a map and it turned out as a Temple to the OctaGod ,with a hole in the basement that dropped you out of the ceiling. I found Second Life and spent 5 years being amazed by the stuff that could be made. This was a dance club I made. New age music to slow dance to,scenic views to meditate in,and concealed beneath it was my store where I sold animated paintings and other stuff. Art is where you find it, and don't be constrained by your choice of mediums .

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Why is the top down learning approach significantly more often taught than the bottom up one?

I think there is something deeply wrong with how beginners are taught. As a child, I drew from children books and worked my way up to cartoons, comics and then photography. This seems to be the natural progression of art, we start with cave drawings and as we notice the complexities of reality we work our way up to oil paintings. Why is it then, that beginners are so often taught to draw from real life? In my humble opinion, this is completely overwhelming to a starter.

Think of it this way - virtually every other skill taught out there goes from simple to complex.

That approach only makes sense if learning as you grow up, a toddler cannot grasp complex life or mechanical drawings, but as their cognition develops, so can their ability to draw more and more accurately.
The problem with teaching like that, is every step of the journey involves unlearning bad habits and shortcuts and replacing them with better ones, that's why drawing is often taught going straight to the point. posts.name: Anonymous

>Why is it then, that beginners are so often taught to draw from real life?
They key word here is FROM. Realism is only hard if you're trying to conjure up imagery purely from your mind.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6474581
This is kind of an open question but it seems most places start teaching with copies from the flat + life drawing. You're right that you need the training wheels first, but you also need to develop the ability to observe from life quickly because it will teach you how the 2d works you copy are "styled." You are consciously or unconsciously building a shape library in your head, so if you just copy 10,000 bad drawings, you're damaging your aesthetic progress. If you are a beg, this is made much worse by the fact that you don't really know what a good drawing is yet. Drawing from life doesn't have this last problem, and will always help you see, depict, and appreciate beauty directly, no matter your skill level.

>>6474581
A lot of it depends on goals. Do you want to improve quickly and suffer, or improve slowly and have fun?
The thing with art education and training is that they are there to improve your skills as efficiently as possible, and what is fun is ultimately up to the student. The instructor would be wasting their students' time by forcing them to do things that won't show as much improvement and may not even be fun to the individual. Things like fun and creativity might not be directly important to improvement, but they can prevent you from getting burnt out and being the type of anon who does nothing but grind, then complains on this board about how art makes him want to kill himself.
If you really want to have fun, it would be better to go find a community somewhere else on the internet with other people who don't take things so seriously, then come back here every once in a while if you actually need something critiqued.

You don't need to draw from a distance. It's always best to double check your whole canvas from time to time, or even better, to have a separate canvas always zoomed out, to make the process faster, but you don't have to always draw like that.

posts.sub: Growing your platform as an artist
posts.com:
What do you do to grow your platform as an artist that wants a large audience?
Do you just post your flavor of the month fanart and let it speak for itself while praying to the algorithm gods?
Or do you create extra content to boost your engagement and reach?
I've been thinking of tapping into video platforms like TikTok but have yet to come up with interesting concepts that isn't just a drawing timelapse + music.
I hate the idea of becoming a content creator but what other choice do you have when simply posting your art doesn't bring any results?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Post good art, consistently. This is the hardest part for people. If your art isn't good - not "lowest common denominator", niche art is fine - and if you don't post enough, you fucking die.

For some platforms this means daily. For others it means between alternating days and 3 times a week.

Don't use it like a personal blog. If you shill paid stuff, make it "there but nonintrusive." Interact with people so you have a personality, and they get that parasocial dopamine hit but don't overdo it.

Don't watermark your stuff to all hell, and use a LEGIBLE, non-intrusive signature so people can find you - reverse image searches don't hit every site. No scribbles.

Post your art in appropriate places, preferably anonymously. Don't link or say anything, just share. If sauce is asked, provide it.
After you get enough traction, if you decide to open some kind of subscription service - leak it to kemono/ehentai/etc.

An artist's value is defined by how often his shit gets reposted. The more people who see your art, the more likely some will want to follow. The more who follow, the more who will want to interact, and the more who interact, the more who will be willing to pay you.
A lot of artists get a portion of this wrong and focus only on followers/watchers as a raw number, but if your art is shared without a lot of extra context then the people who go through the effort to find it are likely going to be "quality followers" rather than "inactive followers." The total follower count only matters in that a portion of that is going to be quality followers.

Note that SOME artists with good enough art (often in a broad enough niche) can compensate for failing in other areas. I have seen artists who shitpost and do the "posting screenshots and food photos" thing on their social media or are constantly blabbering in their journals on galleries, but the art is good enough to enough people that it compensates for it.
Still, if they didn't do that shit they'd be WAY bigger.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6472190
I should also stress that "interacting with people" means the people who are interacting with YOU. Limit it to things "about your art." Thank people if they like it (thank each person who leaves a comment until you're popular enough that it becomes too much.) If using twitter or posting in an art discord or something, don't post reaction images as that disrupts peoples' ability to find your art using ctrl+f "from:anonshithead in:pyw has:image" or the media tab.

If you DO want to use reaction images, draw them. Each time. Draw a new one. This limits how many you show, as well as forcing you to practice more. It also, again, does that dopamine hit of "OHMYGODMYFAVORITEARTISTDREWAREACTIONJUSTFORME" to the followers and encourages more interactions. Just make sure the people who you reply to with it are at least semi-random.

>>6473573
>I post a time lapse reel it gets less engagement and reach than the art work..
Yeah it feels pretty random. Some reels perfom shit and others perform very well.

>should I post both the art and the time lapse at the same time?
I'd spread it out throughout the day. Maybe the 1st post in the morning and the 2nd in the evening.
Don't forget to use your story to promote your posts as well. Your followers won't always see your posts on their timeline because instagram is shit.

>Also any tips to improve my reels?
Showing the finished artwork for 1 second before the timelapse starts, gives the viewer enough of a dopamine hit to keep watching.
It's all about cattering to the adhd brain modern people have.
1 second is enough for the viewer to see but not process the finished artwork.
They become curious and want to keep watching.
Like jingling keys in front of a toddler.
The more impressive and suggestive your artwork, the greater the effect, I have found.

>>6472903
Hi!
I found pic related from a thread some months ago and it has actually been a great blessing for me.
I frequently got advice like
>just draw bro lol
clearly doesn't work. If you are shit at drawing and you draw more shit you aren't actually moving anywhere productive; Usually just stomping on a pile of the same shit making the same mistakes and missing the same key fundamentals over and over again.
>there are so many courses out there!
yes but which one?
>SOOO MANY
plz just tell me one :*(
>SOOOoooOOO MAnY
So here I am to tell you exactly what I did.

Following pic rel I started with CtrlPaint (its free, start with basics). I'm using Krita he's using photoshop. It took me 3 or 4 weeks before we even got to drawing an apple. Every 5 minute video lecture took me an hour of pausing every sentence to google how to do what he said on krita and follow along. Some lessons are missing the .psd download so I just screenshot his video and upload that to krita to follow along. Use your brain. I am 2k% more fluent in krita now thanks to this guy. There is no shortcut. You have to brute force your way through lots of "boring" to actually learn the program and its capabilities thoroughly. I'm hardly a L33T HAXOR now but I went from literally not knowing how to merge a layer or change the brush tag to making my own custom brushes and being basically fluent in the "photo-editing" aspects of the program. I even know where my resource folder is now!

Second, I decided to "sail" marc brunet's art academy. To do this you need to get qBittorent (make sure it's q when you google it). Then google "rutracker marc brunet", translate the page etc. use your brain figure it out (cubebrush). magnet link at the bottom of forum post.
Sail this course (its 36.8 gb). he says if you "attend class" and study for 3-4 hours a day you should finish his course in ~2 years. I just started but I am already so grateful.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6474894
TL;DR independently trying to learn you waste 10 minutes (looking for books, doodling bullshit etc.) for every 1 minute of productive study. These guys (especially brunet) have thought extremely hard about how to get you from A to B in the quickest way. You should 80% study them and 20% study supplemental stuff that you personally like and want to focus on like anime or specific books like scott robertson - how to draw; which I am using to study vehicle and environment design.

I am in a lot of pain all the time I can personally maybe squeeze out like an hour or two of productive fucking anything per day. I have made more real progress in 1 month of CtrPaint + brunet than I have in the previous 5 or 6 months of grinding a few loomis heads every day which only demotivated me and made me depressed. Learning Krita so that I can comfortably draw while lying down in bed on my android has been a gamechanger also instead of trying to draw with pencils and pens and sketchbooks at my tiny fucking desk made for toddlers in my tiny rented bedroom. I understand the advice to start learning analog so you have less distractions but in my case I regret avoiding digital for so long.

Lastly I would say that if you are looking for a specific book you can look up zlibrary on reddit to find out how to access it on the dark web, or you could just google "book name/author name" + "pdf" and I just found like 90% of the books within minutes. Plus check the sticky since the loomis books for example are free (out of copyright?) just get them from there.

Efficiency is key and the advice people give on this board can be really bad. an advanced artist saying "just draw" to a beg is like saying "just sail" from your floating boat to a guy on the beach who has a massive hole in his raft.

I am noticeable progress at this point considering my disability. I think within a few weeks I will be brave enough to post something on the beg thread. for now I hope this helps someone.

-painguy

The assignments are probably the most valuable thing about the course. Take what I say with a grain of salt because I only got the course very recently and I'm still working through CtrlPaint so it may be a little while until I start really focusing on brunet but while I was flipping through the course material I just knew it was for me. Starting term 3 there is feedback videos, 4 videos of feedback he is giving to his students literally an hour long each! I obviously didn't pay for his course so no feedback direct from him or his group but this is the next best thing imo. For me personally when I judge that I am 70-80% of the way there to his example level then I would move on. You keep the material forever so you can always come back to it later if you find you need to go over it again.

He does say in his introductory video that each term should take 2-3 months at an average pace of 3-4 hours of classes and/or practice per day, so basing it on that it should be between 180 (2x30x3) and 360 (3x30x4) hours per term.

His course is extremely beefy. I am personally planning on taking it slow and being very thorough. At my current pace I would guess that starting from term 2 or 3 I will be spending 3 months at least on every term. I like to follow along with what the person is doing in the video on my drawing program and take very detailed notes so I am definitely not working through this as fast as I could be.

Although this is exactly the sort of thing that I wanted. Just put in the hours and get to where you want to be instead of spending hours wasting your time collecting holes in your knowledge from random shit on youtube. The tortoise vs. the hare. Slow and steady wins the race. I don't want to be a fucking beg forever. I would rather take my time and guarantee that I am making progress in the right direction. I don't expect this should be quick and easy but you probably also shouldn't be spending a year on 1 term imo.

>>6475157
It's very simple really. You may want to look up a tutorial on how to torrent in general. RuTracker dot org seems to be down right now but thats the site you want to go to. To translate from Russian to English you should use a browser like Chrome and then press the setting something like "translate this webpage". There will be a link at the bottom of the first forum post of whatever you wanted to download called a magnet. You have to click this special link and your browser will prompt you to open it with your installed torrenting software of choice (you should have qBittorent installed by now btw).

When qBittorent opens it will open the details of the torrent for you to review, including a preview of the files and folders you will be downloading which you can choose which ones to not download if you for example only wanted terms 1-3 instead of all 10. You can also set the destination of the download (I believe by default it is your downloads folder).

Once you click okay the download will start, and depending on many factors like the time of day, your internet connection, your geographic location, the ratio of seeders to leeches etc. it may take less or more time. It took me about 3 hours to download all 36.8 gb.

Also depending on your country or ISP you may want to torrent through a VPN connection (again google it if you are in Germany or something and need to do this).

All in all for saving 400 USD it's worth spending 40 minutes to learn how to torrent something. RuTracker is also a good site to know about generally. You can find lots of stuff there.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6472903
I’ll be honest op, it took me eightish years of ping-ponging back and forth between basic form drills, figure drawing, anatomy, shading, stylization, and basically every other drawing skill you have to learn before I reached competence.

What I’m trying to say is resources can be a good thing, a helpful thing, but realize that learning is not a straight shot from A to Z. It’s a gradual thing where you move from one topic to the next quite randomly and zip back and forth between them over time. You’ll slowly gain understanding and skill.

Remember to have fun and draw what you want to draw. If you wait around until you get good, you’ll be waiting a while. There’s no magic pill that I’m aware of. I remember filling out a lot of printer paper with shitty, stiff figure drawings. I also remember filling pages of boxes and drawing still life that looked wonky and doing more form drawing drills to improve that wonkiness until I was doing clean still life with good form.

Look up marks drawing tutorials on YouTube and see his basic drawing drills. They’re solid if you have trouble with form. For everything else, you kinda have to bounce around and study from various resources until you get it.

Early drawing is filled with a lot of fear, doubt and pain but eventually that melts away with competence, leading into confidence. Keep going anon.

Blindly means without thinking. If someone does something cool, you draw it. No analysis, no thinking. If you mess something up, you fix it. you might spend 200 hours on the same image. By the end, you are simply able to do way more than when you began the image.

Photo studies are bad because they do not teach anything about artistic process. Many artists have a different workflow for photos than they do for personal work, or even master studies (copying other artwork). Photos should be referenced or analyzed. Copying them is often useless, unless the exact image is used for illustration purposes.

Here's my no bullshit method of having good drawing days
>Eat fish for its omega-3 content
Seriously just do it. There's a reason why asians particularly Korean and Japanese are high iq. Omega-3 helps supplement the brain.
>Draw ten 30-second gestures, five 1-minute gestures, and two to three 5-minute gestures.
15~20 mins of warm up sketches like this should be plenty to get your brain running. Think of it like starting up a machine.
>Surround yourself with high quality art that inspires you as much as you possibly can, or take a walk outside in a nice location
You are what you absorb. Most importantly, get off 4chan.

Here's a trick. Having a good drawing day? At the end of your session, start a few rough doodles that you're happy with, but leave them as-is with at most very minimal refining. I needed an excuse to post my schizo theories

It's like anything else, the more you overdo it, the less the subsequent hits provide pleasure. Coupled with it being a learned ability, too little enjoyment derived in any given session will make it hard to continue and make one more prone to mistakes as the frustration builds. I see it as the brain logging learned information, and can only log so much so quickly, so excessive effort will diminish the rewards as the brain is like a SSD which can only read and write data at a set pace, and doing more is unlikely to net gain

A more reliable tactic is to do it regularly over time, counting the total length in terms of weeks and months rather than individual days, which are susceptible to all sorts of whimsy

>>6463664
Why does the top of the femur go all the way to the end his buttcheek? I could be wrong, but doesn't it end to the side of the thigh and not all the way back like you drew it?

The shoulders are shrugging upwards, making them more narrow, the torso is twisted a bit to the side, making it seem thinner, and the hips are sticking outwards, making them look fuller. The tail is wrapping around the legs, giving the buttocks a slight lift, also enhancing the shape. He is posing himself on purpose to LOOK more feminine, but there is nothing actually that off anatomy wise. Reminds me of the specific poses social media models use to trick the viewer into thinking they are curvier.
I think the body retains a decent balance, since the thigh is not thicker than his waist. He is definitely not meant to be a "draw a girl call it a boy" character.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I love /cbsg/.
I love how we have a place where we, the hope-pilled male-enjoyers, can all work hard and support each other so that one day we may achieve our artistic dreams no matter what condition we may arrive in. I love our vision to build each other up so that we may all climb the staircase of greatness together.

Many may not share our vision, many may want to destroy us and everything wonderful we have built here. Many who despise all that is good and beautiful. Many who are referred to as "nodraws". The nodraws may attack a dozen, a hundred, or maybe even a thousand threads, but they will never destroy what we have created here. Because for every flower trampled there will be more to take its place, for every harsh winter there will be a beautiful spring waiting to embrace us in its warmth, and for every forest burned there will be new growth ready to peer through the ashes and share with the world all its beauty.

In the pits of this war-torn landscape, there cannot be despair without hope, there cannot be darkness without light, there cannot be hatred without love, and there cannot be nodraw bottom-feeders without us drawchad gods! Without us, they are nothing. They try to steal from us our happiness and our joy because they have none of their own. Trying to steal from thread after thread without ever realizing that the banquet has been open to all since the very beginning.

Hold your heads up high, sisters. For the brighter we shine the more the nodraws attempt to dim our light. For the more we are unified the more they attempt to divide. For the more we strengthen our souls the more they attack us in desperation, hoping to shatter our hearts to look just like theirs. They push and shove with all their might, only for us to stand as still and tall as our collective resolve.

I love /cbsg/, because to me /cbsg/ is more than a thread: It's a feeling, an idea, a home.

You all have a beautiful Sunday, and happy drawing.

I was hired as a full-time remote concept artist, and a lot of job fliers online these days advertise 100% remote positions as a perk. Better than ping-pong and snack bars if you ask me. My company sold their office and opted for one of those WeWork-style offices where you can rent a space for a few hours for meetings that require in-person interactions and/or work there for "quiet/concentration" if you wanted to.

It's cheaper for companies to let their employees work from home if they can, and you literally have no excuse to turn up late unless you're sick. If you're an artist, they only really need you to deliver the goods within the deadline, with the final revisions included.

Life is good brehs.

Most artists don't get hired because there's not actually enough studios and a lot of smaller ones only exist for a single production or a couple years before collapsing. Either due to being a purpose-made subsidiary given to a specific lead by a larger corp, or from being led by incompetents.

A lot of people see this current state as the only reality, not thinking about anything which can give individuals the ability to grow their own studio WITHOUT VC/angel investor or daddy-corpo funding.
Kickstarter/Indiegogo and so on have been great for this. A lot of concept artists either started their own projects via those or were hired using crowdfunded money. Anything which reduces the barriers to entry for the quality ideas-guys to hire artists is good.
Quality ideas-guys are tested by the market, unfortunately, so without them having already made things, under the current paradigm it's a crapshoot as to whether you'll get a stable job from either a startup, crowdfunded, or brownnoser's first time leading a production.

If only there was something that promised to reduce costs for individuals so they could grow their media/game business into making bigger budget things after already proving their worth... Hmmm HMMM

Ok i'm going to break this down. The clothing, is essentially a rough sketch, the anatomy, while the major forms are there, is simplistic, its correct in every way it needs to be for a cartoon character to look good. the hardest part of drawing a person, getting the hands right, is covered in effectively a sphere, because this is digital, the tedious work of all the action lines to go to a point is done for you with perspective.

This was made by a person who knows anatomy, knows how to use their tools to the fullest, and understands how to shade for illustration, and is likely also good enough with proportions to not need much of if any construction.

now an area where I believe he fucked up, the lines on the left side imply he is moving sharply to the right (image left and right) yet the hair is done in a way where it looks like he is moving left, a minor detail, but when im nitpicking that much to come up with a flaw, it shows the skill.
